4.5.2.1           Impacts from the Proposed Project

Based upon the results of the literature review of archaeological resources and the field inspection,
there is a low potential for the project to impact subsurface prehistoric and/or cultural resources on
the site. It is possible, however, that earthmoving activities associated with future residential
development on the site could uncover some evidence of prehistoric occupation.

4.5.2.2           Program Mitigation and Avoidance Measures

                                  City of Morgan Hill Municipal Code

In accordance with the City of Morgan Hill Municipal Code Chapter 18.75, proposals for the
development of a site identified as archaeologically sensitive by the City's adopted archaeological
sensitivity map shall be subject to the following review process and standard conditions of project
approval:

         The City will consult with the Northwest Information Center for information about whether
          proposed development is located within or adjacent to a known archaeological site, and if it is
          determined that it is so located, then a historical alteration permit is required for the project,
          and subsequent CEQA review of the project shall consider potentially significant impacts on
          archaeological resources and identify appropriate mitigation measures to be imposed as
          conditions of approval in addition to the standard conditions identified below.

         If the project is not located within or adjacent to a known archaeological site, but is located
          within the mapped archaeologically sensitive area as adopted by the City, then the project
          applicant has the option to either have an archaeological survey be completed for the site to
          determine what, if any, conditions of approval will be required as mitigation measures; or
          agree to comply with the following standard conditions of approval, which shall be
          conclusively deemed to reduce potentially significant impacts on archaeological resources to
          a less than significant level (no archaeological resources report is required as part of any
          CEQA review of the project as long as the applicant accepts these conditions and
          incorporates them into the project):

                 An archaeologist shall be present on-site to monitor all ground-disturbing activities.
                  Where historical or archaeological artifacts are found, work in areas where remains or
                  artifacts are found will be restricted or stopped until proper protocols are met, as
                  described below:

                          Work at the location of the find will halt immediately within thirty feet of the
                          find. If an archaeologist is not present at the time of the discovery, the
                          applicant shall contact an archaeologist for evaluation of the find to determine
                          whether it qualifies as a unique archaeological resource as defined by this
                          chapter;
                          If the find is determined not to be a Unique Archaeological Resource,
                          construction can continue. The archaeologist will prepare a brief informal
                          memo/letter that describes and assesses the significance of the resource,
                          including a discussion of the methods used to determine significance for the
                          find;
                          If the find appears significant and to qualify as a unique archaeological
                          resource, the archaeologist will determine if the resource can be avoided and
                          will detail avoidance procedures in a formal memo/letter; and

City of Morgan Hill                                                                            Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                       35                                        August 2009
                        If the resource cannot be avoided, the archaeologist shall develop within
                        forty-eight hours an action plan to avoid or minimize impacts. The field crew
                        shall not proceed until the action plan is approved by the community
                        development director. The action plan shall be in conformance with
                        California Public Resources Code 21083.2.

       All development projects located within an archaeological sensitivity area and/or containing
        known archaeological resources on-site shall also be subject to the following measures as
        standard conditions of project approval:

               This project may adversely impact undocumented human remains or unintentionally
                discover significant historic or archaeological materials. The following policies and
                procedures for treatment and disposition of inadvertently discovered human remains
                or archaeological materials shall apply. If human remains are discovered, it is
                probable they are the remains of Native Americans.

                        If human remains are encountered they shall be treated with dignity and
                        respect as due to them. Discovery of Native American remains is a very
                        sensitive issue and serious concern. Information about such a discovery shall
                        be held in confidence by all project personnel on a need to know basis. The
                        rights of Native Americans to practice ceremonial observances on sites, in
                        labs and around artifacts shall be upheld.
                        Remains should not be held by human hands. Surgical gloves should be worn
                        if remains need to be handled.
                        Surgical mask should also be worn to prevent exposure to pathogens that may
                        be associated with the remains.

               In the event that known or suspected Native American remains are encountered or
                significant historic or archaeological materials are discovered, ground-disturbing
                activities shall be immediately stopped. Examples of significant historic or
                archaeological materials include, but are not limited to, concentrations of historic
                artifacts (e.g., bottles, ceramics) or prehistoric artifacts (chipped chert or obsidian,
                arrow points, groundstone mortars and pestles), culturally altered ash-stained midden
                soils associated with pre-contact Native American habitation sites, concentrations of
                fire-altered rock and/or burned or charred organic materials, and historic structure
                remains such as stone-lined building foundations, wells or privy pits. Ground-
                disturbing project activities may continue in other areas that are outside the exclusion
                zone as defined below.

               An "exclusion zone" where unauthorized equipment and personnel are not permitted
                shall be established (e.g., taped off) around the discovery area plus a reasonable
                buffer zone by the Contractor Foreman or authorized representative, or party who
                made the discovery and initiated these protocols, or if on-site at the time or discovery,
                by the Monitoring Archaeologist (typically 25-50ft for single burial or archaeological
                find).
               The exclusion zone shall be secured (e.g., 24 hour surveillance) as directed by the
                City or County if considered prudent to avoid further disturbances.

               The Contractor Foreman or authorized representative, or party who made the
                discovery and initiated these protocols shall be responsible for immediately


City of Morgan Hill                                                                          Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                     36                                        August 2009
                contacting by telephone the parties listed below to report the find and initiate the
                consultation process for treatment and disposition:

                        The City of Morgan Hill Community Development Director
                        The Contractor's Point(s) of Contact
                        The Coroner of the County of Santa Clara (if human remains found)
                        The Native American Heritage Commission (NAHC) in Sacramento
                        The Amah Mutsun Tribal Band

               The Coroner has two working days to examine the remains after being notified of the
                discovery. If the remains are Native American the Coroner has 24 hours to notify the
                NAHC.

               The NAHC is responsible for identifying and immediately notifying the Most Likely
                Descendant (MLD) from the Amah Mutsun Tribal Band. (Note: NAHC policy holds
                that the Native American Monitor will not be designated the MLD.)

               Within 24 hours of their notification by the NAHC, the MLD will be granted
                permission to inspect the discovery site if they so choose.

               Within 24 hours of their notification by the NAHC, the MLD may recommend to the
                City's community development director the recommended means for treating or
                disposing, with appropriate dignity, the human remains and any associated grave
                goods. The recommendation may include the scientific removal and non-destructive
                or destructive analysis of human remains and items associated with Native American
                burials. Only those osteological analyses or DNA analyses recommended by the
                Amah Mutsun Tribal Band may be considered and carried out.

               If the MLD recommendation is rejected by the City of Morgan Hill the parties will
                attempt to mediate the disagreement with the NAHC. If mediation fails then the
                remains and all associated grave offerings shall be reburied with appropriate dignity
                on the property in a location not subject to further subsurface disturbance.

Implementation of these standard measures would ensure that development allowed under the
proposed General Plan amendment would not result in significant impacts to archaeological
resources.

4.5.3           Conclusion

Implementation of the standard measures and laws and regulations listed above, including the
Morgan Hill Municipal Code, would avoid possible impacts to buried archaeological resources from
future development on the site. (Less Than Significant Impact)




City of Morgan Hill                                                                          Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                     37                                        August 2009
4.6              GEOLOGY AND SOILS

4.6.1            Setting

4.6.1.1          Soils

According to the City of Morgan Hill's Geology, Geologic, and Geological Hazards Study, soils on
the majority of the project site consist of unconsolidated colluvium, valley floor alluvium, or terrace
deposits on flat or nearly flat ground. Soils of this type may be subject to settlement under seismic or
aseismic conditions. Small portions of the northwestern and southern corners of the site contain soils
consisting of moderately to highly expansive alluvial or colluvial soil on flat or nearly flat ground.
Soils of this type may be subject to seasonal shrinking and swelling, soil creep, and settlement. Soils
on the western boundary of the site in the immediate vicinity of Fisher Creek are classified as
naturally infilled stream channels and fill placed without geotechnical control that occupy flat or
nearly flat ground. Soils of this type may be subject to vertical settlement. The entire site is
classified as valley floor terrain where ground water has been measured at least once, since about
1950, to be within 15 feet of the ground surface.

Most of soils on the site are described in Soils of Santa Clara County (1968) as Pleasanton loam.
Pleasanton loam has a moderate potential for expansion. Soils on the western boundary of the site, in
the immediate vicinity of Fisher Creek, are described as Los Osos clay loam (LoF). Los Osos clay
loam has a high potential for expansion. Expansive soils shrink and swell as a result of moisture
changes. These changes can cause heaving and cracking of slabs-on-grade, pavements and structures
found on shallow foundations. Because the site topography is flat, there is no erosion or landslide
hazard.

4.6.1.2          Seismicity

The San Francisco Bay Area is one of the most seismically active regions in the United States. An
earthquake of moderate to high magnitude generated within the San Francisco Bay region could
cause considerable ground shaking at the project site. The degree of shaking is dependent on the
magnitude of the event, the distance to its zone of rupture and local geologic conditions.

The three major faults in the region are the San Andreas Fault, the Calaveras Fault, and the Hayward
Fault. The San Andreas Fault runs north/south and parallel to the Hayward Fault and the Calaveras
Fault. The San Andreas Fault is approximately 10 miles west of the site, the Calaveras Fault is
approximately four miles east of the site, and the Hayward Fault is approximately 10 miles northeast
of the site. The project site is not located within a fault rupture zone. 3




3
  U.S. Geological Survey and California Geological Survey, Quaternary Fault and Fold Database for the United
States, accessed June 15, 2009. http://earthquake.usgs.gov/regional/qfaults/.


City of Morgan Hill                                                                               Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                        38                                          August 2009
                                                    Liquefaction

Soil liquefaction is a condition where saturated granular soils near the ground surface undergo a
substantial loss of strength during seismic events. Loose, water-saturated soils are transformed from
a solid to a liquid state during ground shaking. Liquefaction can result in significant deformations.
Soils most susceptible to liquefaction are loose, uniformly graded, saturated, fine-grained sands that
lie close to the ground surface. According to the City of Morgan Hill's Geology, Geologic, and
Geological Hazards Study, the entire site is classified as valley floor terrain where ground water has
been measured at least once, since about 1950, to be within 15 feet of the ground surface. Areas of
potential shallow groundwater are also areas of potential soil liquefaction. 4

4.6.2.1            Impacts from the Proposed Project

The project proponent proposes a General Plan amendment to change the land use designation on the
site from Public Facilities to Single Family Medium (3-5 dwelling units per acre). This will allow
the future development of up to150 single-family units on the site. The project site is located in a
seismically active region and in an area with a potential for soil liquefaction. Soils with moderate to
high potential for expansion are also present on the site. Impacts to future development on the site
from geology soil conditions can be minimized through the use of standard engineering and seismic
safety design techniques. Future building design and construction would be completed in
conformance with a project-specific soil survey and geotechnical report, if warranted, and reviewed
by the City of Morgan Hill Building Division as a standard condition of development. The buildings
will be required to meet the requirements of appropriate Building and Fire Codes, as adopted by the
City of Morgan Hill.

Future development on the site will be required to prepare an Erosion Control Plan as a standard
condition prior to issuance of a building and/or site development permit, subject to review and
approval of the Public Works Department. Conformance with the measures in the erosion control
plan would reduce soil erosion during future construction.

4.6.2.2            Program Mitigation and Avoidance Measures

                                     City of Morgan Hill General Plan

Many of the policies in the City's General Plan were adopted for the purpose of avoiding or
mitigating environmental effects that could result from development planned within the City. All
future development is subject to General Plan policies, including the following, which will reduce or
avoid geologic and seismic impacts:

         Environmental Hazards Policy 1a  Limit uses on lands with geologic hazards.

         Environmental Hazards Policy 1c  Direct site preparation in hazardous areas at long-term
          geologic stability.

         Environmental Hazards Policy 1d  Known or potential geologic, fire, and flood hazards
          should be reported as part of every real estate transaction, as well as recordation on
          documents to be reported for building permits, subdivisions and land development reports.
          Mitigation of hazards should be noted in the same manner.



City of Morgan Hill                                                                                              Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                               40                                                  August 2009
       Environmental Hazards Policy 1g  New development should avoid hazardous and sensitive
        areas, and should occur only where it can be built without risking health and safety. New
        habitable structures should not be allowed in areas of highest hazard such as floodways,
        active landslides, active fault traces, and airport safety zones. In areas of less risk,
        development should be limited and designed to reduce risks to an acceptable level. (SCJAP
        15.00)

       Environmental Hazards Policy 1k  Regulate development in hazardous areas in such a way
        that it minimizes disruption of the environment and does not trigger or accelerate the
        hazardous processes which exist in South County (SCJAP 15.02b)

       Environmental Hazards Policy 1n  Cluster development in hazardous areas with dwellings
        grouped on the least hazardous portion of the property. (SCJAP 15.02e)

       Environmental Hazards Actions 1.1  Continue to require geologic studies for development
        in hillside areas and geotechnical studies for critical facilities in areas with liquefiable soils.

       Environmental Hazards Action 2.7  Require geotechnical investigations on all projects in
        unstable areas, including areas of expansive soils, prior to construction to insure that the
        potential hazards are identified and can be properly mitigated. (SCJAP 15.13)

       Environmental Hazards Action 2.10 Contract with a consulting geologist for the review of
        development projects in potentially hazardous areas with costs covered by a fee to the
        developer (SCJAP 15.13b)

                               City of Morgan Hill Standard Measures

       Future building design and construction would be completed in conformance with a project-
        specific soil survey and geotechnical report, if warranted, and reviewed by the City of
        Morgan Hill Building Division as a standard condition of development. The buildings will
        be required to meet the requirements of appropriate Building and Fire codes, as adopted by
        the City of Morgan Hill.

       Future development on the site will be required to prepare an Erosion Control Plan as a
        standard condition prior to issuance of a building and/or site development permit, subject to
        review and approval of the Public Works Department. Conformance with the measures in
        the erosion control plan would reduce soil erosion during future construction.

4.6.3           Conclusion

Implementation of the General Plan policies and standard measures discussed above would avoid
geology and soil impacts at the time of future development on the site. (Less Than Significant
Impact)




City of Morgan Hill                                                                             Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                       41                                         August 2009
4.7       HAZARDS AND HAZARDOUS MATERIALS

The following discussion is based upon a Phase I Site Assessment and a Soil Sampling and Analysis
Report prepared for the project site by E2C, Inc. in September 2000 and July 2001, respectively.

4.7.1           Setting

A review of available historical aerial photographs revealed that the site has been in agricultural
production since before at least 1950, and it has never been developed. This was confirmed in
conversations with the property owner who has personal knowledge of uses on the site for the 20
years prior to completion of the Phase I Site Assessment.

During the site reconnaissance, no evidence of existing underground or aboveground storage tanks
was observed on the site or on the accessible areas of the adjacent properties. The vegetation on the
site shows no obvious signs of abnormal biological stress, which can be an indicator of subsurface
contamination. No pits, ponds, or lagoons were observed on the site, nor were there any pools of
suspect liquids on the site. No discernible odors were noticed at the site. At the time of the site visit,
no Asbestos-Containing Building Materials (ACBMs) were observed on the site, including those that
might have been dumped there.

On the adjacent parcel to the north, a PG&E-owned pole-mounted transformer was observed
approximately 1,400 feet from the project site. On this same parcel, a large, abandoned, empty
metal container was observed. The soil and plants surrounding this container did not appear to be
stained, disturbed, or stressed. Union Pacific Railroad lines are located approximately 15 to 20 feet
east of the project site.

4.7.1.1         Field Investigation Results

Because the project site was in agricultural production before the use of DDT and certain other toxic
chemicals was banned in 1972, 15 areas of the site were sampled for hazardous materials. Samples
were collected from near surface sample locations. All samples were collected in glass jars and
transported to a state-certified laboratory to be analyzed for organochlorine and organohalide
pesticides (including DDD, DDT, and DDE), lead, and arsenic.

No pesticides or arsenic were detected in any of the samples collected on the project site. Only low
concentrations of lead, below the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) mandated Preliminary
Remediation Goals (PRGs), were detected.

4.7.1.2         Review of Agency Files

As part of the Phase I Site Assessment, a search of applicable regulatory databases was completed to
identify properties with documented environmental releases and/or those that use, store, or dispose of
regulated chemicals. The identification of contaminated or hazardous materials sites is important to
avoid potential land use compatibility and public safety impacts. The project site is not listed on any
of the databases searched as part of the Phase I report. One leaking underground storage tank was
documented on a site within one-half mile north of the project site. This site is a gas station located
at 19490 Monterey Road. A waste oil tank and surrounding soil was removed from that site and the
case has been closed. While the report describes that the aquifer was affected, the site is located
downgradient of the groundwater flow in the project area. Therefore, it is unlikely that this leak has
impacted the project site.


City of Morgan Hill                                                                           Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                      42                                        August 2009
The "Geotracker" database, maintained by the State Water Resources Control Board, lists sites with
leaking underground tanks, underground tank wells, as well as some landfills. This database includes
approximately 115 sites in Morgan Hill, many of which are located in the downtown area along the
Monterey Road corridor. As of July 2009, the project site was not listed on local or state databases
[i.e., State Water Resources Control Board (Geotracker) or the Santa Clara County leaking
underground tank program] as a hazardous materials site where there is known contamination.

4.7.2.1            Impacts from the Proposed Project

The project proponent proposes a General Plan amendment to change the land use designation on the
site from Public Facilities to Single Family Medium (3-5 dwelling units per acre). This will allow
the future development of up to 150 single-family units on the site. As previously described, there is
no indication of past use of hazardous materials on the project site. Only low levels of lead were
found during sub-surface testing, which were well below the EPA mandated PRG values. Therefore,
excavation of soil on the site related to future residential development is not expected to result in
health risks to construction workers and/or the public.

The project site is located within one-half mile of a recorded hazardous materials site. While the
aquifer was affected by a leaking waste oil tank, the recorded site is located down-gradient from the
project site and the case has been closed. Therefore, it is not expected that the project site would be
affected by the waste oil leak.

4.7.2.2            Program Mitigation and Avoidance Measures

                                      City of Morgan Hill General Plan

Many of the policies in the City's General Plan were adopted for the purpose of avoiding or
mitigating environmental effects that could result from development planned within the City. All
future development is subject to General Plan policies, including the following, which will reduce or
avoid risk from exposure to soil contamination:

         Hazardous Materials Policy 3t  Provide mitigation to remedy the effects of new or
          expanding development over areas with environmental contamination of any and all
          unauthorized discharges.




City of Morgan Hill                                                                                           Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                             44                                                 August 2009
4.7.3           Conclusion

Implementation of the General Plan policies and standard measures discussed above would reduce or
avoid possible exposure to residual agricultural chemicals at the time of possible future development.
(Less Than Significant Impact)




City of Morgan Hill                                                                       Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                    45                                      August 2009
4.8              HYDROLOGY AND WATER QUALITY

Portions of the following discussion are based in part upon a hydrology report completed for the
MHCHS FEIR in June 2001, by Schaaf & Wheeler, Consulting Civil Engineers, a memo dated
September 14, 2001 from Schaaf & Wheeler, Consulting Civil Engineers, and a drainage report
completed for the MHCHS FEIR in September 2001, by MH Engineering.

4.8.1            Setting

4.8.1.1          Drainage and Flooding

The project site is located in the Fisher Creek watershed. Runoff from the project site currently
drains into Fisher Creek, which runs along the western boundary of the project site, adjacent to Hale
Avenue. The site is relatively flat and slopes gently downward towards the creek and Hale Avenue.
In the vicinity of the project site Fisher Creek is a roadside drainage, ranging between five and eight
feet in width at the base and is about five feet deep. The project site is undeveloped, and, as a result,
the runoff rates from the site during storm events are low.

According to the Federal Emergency Management Agency's (FEMA) Flood Insurance Rate Map
(FIRM) 5, the flood designation for the majority of the project site is shown as Zone D, "areas of
undetermined, but possible, flood hazards". A portion of the property near the southern end of the
site is shown as Zone B, "areas between limits of the 100-year flood and 500-year flood; or certain
areas subject to 100-year flooding with average depths less than one (1) foot or where the
contributing drainage area is less than one square mile". 6

During a 100-year flood event, Fisher Creek receives floodwaters from four contributing areas, as
follows:

                overflows from West Little Llagas Creek,
                outflow from the Morgan Hill Business Park detention basin,
                outflow from the Sutter Business Park detention basin, and
                runoff from the upstream portion of the Fisher Creek watershed.

The existing creek does not have sufficient capacity to carry the 100-year peak discharge. During a
100-year flood event, both banks of the creek would be overtopped and the floodplain for the creek
would extend onto Hale Avenue to the west and onto the project site to the east.




5
  An updated FIRM for the project area went into effect on May 18, 2009 (Federal Emergency Management
Agency, Flood Insurance Rate Map, Community Panel Number 06085C 0443H). This FIRM does not include flood
zone designations on the project site, but does show designations in the immediate vicinity to the north, south, and
east. The area surrounding the site is designated as Zone X, which is defined as "Areas of 0.2% annual chance of
flood; areas of 1% annual chance of flood with average depths of less than 1 foot or with drainage areas less than 1
square mile; and areas protected by levees from 1% annual chance flood." It is likely that much of the project site
would be designated Zone X if the FIRM is updated to include the site. South of the site, the updated FIRM
designates areas in and around Hale Avenue as Zone AH, which is a 100-year flood zone with "Flood depths of 1 to
3 feet (usually areas of ponding); Base Flood Elevations determined." It is possible that this designation would
continue to the western border of the project site. Flood zone designations related to the portion of Fisher Creek
located adjacent to the project site are also not shown on this FIRM.
6
  Source: Federal Emergency Management Agency, Flood Insurance Rate Map, Community Panel Number 060337
0445E, August 17, 1998.

City of Morgan Hill                                                                                   Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                          46                                            August 2009
4.8.1.2          Dam Failure and Seiche

Dams located near Morgan Hill include Anderson Dam and Chesbro Dam. According to the
Association of Bay Area Governments (ABAG), almost all of the Valley Floor terrain in Morgan Hill
is within the area that would be inundated if these dams were to fail with reservoirs at full capacity. 7
The "worst case" flood of the entire valley is very unlikely, given that it would require both failure
and full capacity conditions to occur at the same time. The project site is located in the dam failure
inundation area of Anderson Dam. 8
A seiche is defined as a wave generated by rapid displacement of water within a reservoir or lake,
due to an earthquake that triggers land movement within the water body or landsliding into or
beneath the water body. The project site is not located near a water body that is susceptible to seiche
hazard.

4.8.1.3          Groundwater

The site is located within an area in the City of Morgan Hill with recorded groundwater levels of 15
feet or less. 9

4.8.1.4          Water Quality

The site is unpaved and undeveloped. The primary non-point source pollutants from the site would
be sediment and plant debris. Storm water runoff from the project site and surrounding area is
released into Fisher Creek. Fisher Creek is a tributary of Coyote Creek, which flows north and
eventually drains to the San Francisco Bay.

The water quality of ponds, creeks, streams, and other surface water-bodies can be greatly affected
by pollution carried in contaminated surface runoff. Pollutants from unidentified sources, known as
"non-point" source pollutants, are washed from streets, construction sites, parking lots, and other
exposed surfaces into storm drains. Stormwater runoff often contains contaminants such as oil and
grease, plant and animal debris (e.g., leaves, dust, animal feces, etc.) pesticides, litter, and heavy
metals. In sufficient concentration, these pollutants have been found to adversely affect the aquatic
habitats to which they drain.

                                           Regulatory Overview

The State Water Resources Control Board (SWRCB) is responsible for implementation of the
National Pollution Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) Program. The Central Coast RWQCB
issues and enforces NPDES permits for discharges to water-bodies in the portion of Santa Clara
County that drains to the Monterey Bay. Projects disturbing more than one acre of land during
construction are required to file a Notice of Intent (NOI) to be covered under the State NPDES
General Construction Permit for discharges of storm water associated with construction activities.

The State NPDES General Construction Permit requires development and implementation of a Storm
Water Pollution Prevention Plan (SWPPP) and uses storm water Best Management Practices (BMPs)
to control runoff, erosion, and sedimentation from the site both during and after construction. The
7
  ABAG compiled the dam failure inundation hazard maps submitted to the State Office of Emergency Services by
dam owners throughout the Bay Area.
8
  Association of Bay Area Governments, Dam Failure Inundation Hazard Map for Morgan Hill, 1995.
http://www.abag.ca.gov/cgi-bin/pickdamx.pl
9
  Source: Pacific Geotechnical Engineering, Generalized Hydrogeologic and Liquefaction Potential Map of Valley
Floor Terrain, City of Morgan Hill, December 1991.

City of Morgan Hill                                                                               Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                        47                                          August 2009
SWPPP has two major objectives: 1) to help identify the sources of sediments and other pollutants
that affect the quality of storm water discharges; and 2) to describe and ensure the implementation of
practices to reduce sediment and other pollutants in storm water discharges.

4.8.2.1         Impacts from the Proposed Project

The project proponent proposes a General Plan amendment to change the land use designation on the
site from Public Facilities to Single Family Medium (3-5 dwelling units per acre). This will allow
the future development of up to150 single-family units on the site.

                                     Drainage and Flooding Impacts

Future development would add impervious surfaces to the currently undeveloped site, and thereby
increase stormwater runoff from the site. The existing creek channel does not have capacity to
convey the 100-year storm event. Future development on the site would exceed the existing drainage
capacity and increase the potential for flood-related property loss from a 100-year flood.

Impact HYD-1: Future development on the site would exceed the existing drainage capacity and
increase the potential for flood-related property loss from a 100-year flood. (Significant Impact)

                                            Water Quality Impacts

Future construction activities could increase the amount of pollution carried in runoff from the site.
Future development projects on the site will be required to prepare an Erosion Control Plan as a
standard condition prior to issuance of building and/or site development permit, subject to review and
approval of the Public Works Department. Conformance with the measures in the erosion control
plan would reduce the potential for substantial adverse impacts to water quality during construction.

In accordance with the City of Morgan Hill Standard Conditions of Approval and the General
National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System Storm Water Permit for Construction Activities,
future development projects would prepare a Storm Water Pollution Prevention Plan (SWPPP) and
an Erosion Control Plan (ECP). The plans would be submitted to the Director of Public Works and
Central Coast Regional Water Quality Control Board for review and approval, prior to issuance of a
building permit. The ECP and SWPPP would demonstrate how the project would eliminate or
reduce non-stormwater discharges into the stormwater system, how discharges into the stormwater
system would be monitored, and what Best Management Practices (BMPs) would be implemented by

City of Morgan Hill                                                                                            Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                              49                                                 August 2009
the project to avoid water quality impacts during construction (e.g., street sweeping, fiber rolls,
temporary cover and/or permanent cover) and post-construction periods.

4.8.2.2           Program Mitigation and Avoidance Measures

                                   City of Morgan Hill General Plan

Many of the policies in the City's General Plan were adopted for the purpose of avoiding or
mitigating environmental effects that could result from development planned within the City. All
future development is subject to General Plan policies, including the following, which will reduce or
avoid hydrology and water quality impacts:

         Flood Control Policy 4a  Prepare for impacts associated with potential failure of Anderson
          Dam.

         Flood Control Policy 4b  Prohibit development in floodways and regulate in floodplains to
          minimize flood damage and be consistent with the federal flood insurance program and Santa
          Clara Valley Water District regulations. (SCJAP 15.05)

         Flood Control Policy 4e  Natural streamside and riparian areas should be left in their natural
          state in order to preserve their value as percolation and recharge areas, natural habitat, scenic
          resources, recreation corridors and for bank stabilization. (SCJAP 15.08)

         Flood Control Policy 4f  Minimize disruption of natural riparian areas by flood control
          projects needed to protect presently existing development by maintaining slow flow and
          stable banks through design and other appropriate mitigation measures. (SCJAP 15.08)

         Flood Control Policy 4h  Areas which are developed or planned for development should be
          protected by the construction of flood control facilities. Development should be managed
          through advanced planning and design standards to minimize off-site flooding and drainage
          problems. (SCJAP 12.00)

         Flood Control Policy 4k  Require developers whose proposed projects would induce
          downstream flooding to provide mitigation to eliminate the flood-inducing impacts of their
          projects. (SCJAP 12.03)

         Flood Control Policy 4l  If development is to be allowed in flood-prone areas, provide flood
          control facilities or appropriate flood-proofing prior to or in conjunction with development at
          developers' expense. (SCJAP 12.05)

         Flood Control Policy 4m  Where other mitigation measures do not solve the flooding
          problem, permit raising individual foundations (padding up structures) in appropriate
          situations; however, its use must be restricted in order to minimize the cumulative effects on
          adjacent areas. (SCJAP 12.06)

         Flood Control Policy 4n  Require mitigation of any storm water runoff produced by
          development that occurs beyond that described in the General Plans of the City and County
          as of 1982. (SCJAP 12.07)




City of Morgan Hill                                                                            Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                       50                                        August 2009
       Flood Control Policy 4o  Require all local development to provide appropriate mitigation of
        off-site flooding impacts, including limiting runoff to pre-development levels and/or
        complete solutions to flooding and local drainage problems in the vicinity of the
        development, using such methods as detention or retention. (SCJAP 12.08)

       Flood Control Policy 4p  Require careful consideration of the cumulative effects of
        development which would drain into the upper reaches of Llagas Creek and other creeks, in
        order to avoid the need for channelization and consequent destruction of its riparian
        vegetation and natural habitat. (SCJAP 12.09)

       Water Quality Policy 5a  Protect water quality from contamination, and monitor it to assure
        the present policies and regulations are adequate. Prohibit such uses as waste facilities, septic
        systems, and industries using toxic chemicals where polluting substances may come in
        contact with groundwater, floodwaters, and creeks, or reservoir waters. (SCJAP 8.00)

       Water Quality Policy 6g  Encourage the protection, restoration, and enhancement of
        remaining native grasslands, oak woodlands, marshlands and riparian habitat.

                                City of Morgan Hill Municipal Code

In accordance with Morgan Hill Municipal Code Chapter 18.42, future construction on the site will
be required to comply with the City of Morgan Hill Flood Damage Prevention Ordinance, including
elevation of habitable spaces above anticipated flood levels.

4.8.3           Conclusion

Implementation of the General Plan policies and standard measures discussed above would reduce or
avoid drainage and water quality impacts at the time of possible future development to a less than
significant level. (Less Than Significant Impact With Mitigation Incorporated)




City of Morgan Hill                                                                          Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                     51                                        August 2009
4.9             LAND USE

4.9.1           Setting

The project site is currently used for agricultural purposes, and has been dry farmed as recently as
2001, although it has not been farmed in recent years. There are no structures on the project site.
Land uses surrounding the project site include residential, commercial, industrial, and open space.
Land uses east of the project site, beyond the railroad tracks and Monterey Highway, include
commercial land uses and industrial land uses. The areas north and south of the project site are
developed with single family residences. Rural land uses are located west of the project site, across
Hale Avenue. An aerial photograph of the project site with surrounding land uses is shown on Figure
3.

4.9.1.1         General Plan and Zoning

According to the City of Morgan Hill's General Plan Land Use Diagram, the General Plan land use
designation for the project site is Public Facilities. The project site is currently zoned Public
Facilities.

4.9.2.1         Impacts from the Proposed Project

The project proponent proposes a General Plan amendment to change the land use designation on the
site from Public Facilities to Single Family Medium (3-5 dwelling units per acre). This will allow
the future development of up to 150 single-family units on the site.

The applicant has stated an objective to accommodate about 120 dwelling units on the site. Under
Morgan Hill's current general plan designations and zoning regulations, density is calculated based
on gross site area, and therefore the Single Family Medium designation and R1-7,000 zoning would
be the most appropriate categories to accommodate the applicant's project objectives.

City of Morgan Hill                                                                                           Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                             52                                                 August 2009
                             Possible Changes to City of Morgan Hill
                          General Plan Designations and Zoning Districts

As previously discussed, the City of Morgan Hill has held public hearings and is preparing to adopt a
new "Single Family High (5-10 units/acre)" general plan land use designation and zoning, along with
changes to its definition of lot area to shift from "gross" to "net" as the basis of calculating density.
The new district would allow for lot sizes of less than 7,000 square feet, such as 5,000 and 6,000
square foot lots with detached single family units.

The Hale-Signature project site will need to accommodate the Madrone Parkway extension and
project roads, Fisher Creek and appropriate creek setbacks, on-site stormwater detention area, and
possible buffers from the UPRR and/or possible park area. It is possible changes to the definitions of
the lot sizes will be made to the zoning code in the near future and that the Hale-Signature project
could decide that the preferred method of achieving the project objectives under the City's new
regulations would be to instead apply the new Single Family High designation and zoning if it is
adopted and available as an option.

Throughout this Initial Study and in the Transportation Impact Analysis, the description will continue
to reflect the Single Family Medium (3-5 dwelling units per acre) zoning district, but this will also be
interpreted to include designation as "Single Family High" if that option becomes available and the
applicant modifies the proposed project to that new designation as the preferred method of achieving
the assumed project housing type (about 5 units per gross acre or about 7 units per net acre) that is
analyzed by this Initial Study.

A comparison of the development standards under the existing Single-Family Medium Density (R1-
7000) zoning and the currently proposed Single-Family High Density (R1-4500) zoning is provided
in Table 4.9-1. The following discussion notes where development with smaller lots sizes envisioned
under Single Family High zoning could differ in land use characteristics or result in land use
conflicts.

                                           Table 4.9-1:
                           Comparison of Zoning Development Standards
                                                       Min. Setbacks
                                 Min. Lot                                          Maximum
                                  Area             Front          Rear              Height
                                                  Setback        Setback
               Existing                         20 ft 1-story 20 ft 1-story
                R-1 7000           7,000        25 ft 2-story 25 ft 2-story           30 ft
               Proposed                                        15 ft 1-story
                R-1 4500*          4,500            15 ft      20 ft 2-story          35 ft
               *
                It should be noted that these site development standards have not been adopted
               and, therefore, could be modified by City Council.

                                            Land Use Conflicts

Land use conflicts can arise from two basic causes: 1) a new development or land use may cause
impacts to persons or the physical environment in the vicinity of the project site or elsewhere; or 2)
conditions on or near the project site may have impacts on persons or development introduced onto
the site by the project. Both of these circumstances are aspects of land use compatibility. Potential
incompatibility may arise from placing a particular development or land use at an inappropriate
location, or from some aspect of the project's design or scope. Depending on the nature of the


City of Morgan Hill                                                                              Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                        53                                         August 2009
impact and its severity, land use compatibility conflicts can range from minor irritations and nuisance
to potentially significant effects on human health and safety.

The proposed land use designation of Single Family Medium (3-5 dwelling units per gross acre) is
compatible with the surrounding residential, rural, commercial, and industrial land uses. Residential
development on the site may, however, result in increased noise levels in the project area, and future
construction would also result in temporary noise impacts. Temporary air quality impacts may also
result during the construction of the project. Residential land uses are considered sensitive receptors.
Sections 4.11 Noise and 4.3 Air Quality, of this Initial Study, discuss these impacts in greater detail
and provide measures to reduce these impacts to a less than significant level.

Future residential development on the site would not physically divide an established community,
nor would it conflict with any applicable plans, policies, or regulations.

                 Possible Change to Single-Family High Designation and Zoning

While the Single-Family High Density zoning being considered by the City of Morgan Hill as a
separate project would allow smaller lot sizes, slightly smaller setbacks and taller maximum heights,
development under these standards would not result in substantially greater visual intrusion or other
land use compatibility impacts than development under the proposed Single-Family Medium Density
zoning (refer to Table 4.9-1). The proposed use (single family residential) would be compatible with
surrounding residential, rural, commercial, and industrial land uses whether at medium or high
density.

4.9.2.2         Impacts to the Proposed Project

Single family residences are considered sensitive receptors. The project site is located adjacent to
two major roadways (Hale Avenue and Monterey Road) and the Union Pacific Railroad tracks. The
existing Morgan Hill General Plan Circulation Element includes a future Madrone Parkway
extension improvement, which would be a four-lane arterial roadway that would include an at-grade
crossing over the UPRR tracks on the eastern edge of the site. The planned Madrone Parkway
extension identified in the city's Circulation Element will remain unchanged by the Hale-Signature
project application, but it should be recognized that the City of Morgan Hill is currently studying a
General Plan Circulation Element Amendment to modify the existing planned 4 lane arterial at-grade
crossing of the site, to be a 2 lane arterial grade-separated crossing. The General Plan Land Use
Amendment and rezoning of the site can accommodate either circulation network decision, i.e. to
keep the General Plan as it currently exists or to amend it with regard to the planned Madrone
Parkway extension improvement.

As a result of either version of the Madrone Parkway extension, noise levels at the project site can be
expected to be high. Section 4.11 Noise, of this Initial Study, discusses the noise impacts of the
roadways and railroad tracks in greater detail and provides measures to reduce these impacts to a less
than significant level.




City of Morgan Hill                                                                         Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                     54                                       August 2009
4.9.2.3          Program Mitigation and Avoidance Measures

                                       Morgan Hill General Plan

Many of the policies in the City's General Plan were adopted for the purpose of avoiding or
mitigating environmental effects that could result from development planned within the City. All
future development is subject to General Plan policies, including the following, which will reduce or
avoid impacts:

         Incompatible Uses Policy 6a  Avoid development in areas of natural hazards such as
          landslide and flood prone areas.

         Incompatible Uses Policy 6b  Encourage the clustering of residential units to provide open
          space and recreation areas, and to provide buffer areas between different land uses (e.g.,
          industrial and residential).

         Incompatible Uses Policy 6c  Evaluate potential impacts of development projects on
          adjacent uses in initial environmental assessments and EIRs.

         Neighborhoods Policy 8a  Maintain distinct boundaries between commercial uses and
          residential neighborhood. (This does not preclude residential uses within commercial areas
          as part of mixed-use projects, or in designated mixed use areas.)

         Neighborhoods Policy 8e  Design residential neighborhoods so they are distinct and
          separated from conflicting non-residential uses.

         Edges Policy 15d  Feathering from higher urban densities to lower rural densities should
          occur within the city limits. Feathering should begin as development nears the Urban Limit
          Line.

                                Morgan Hill City Council Policy 05-02

In July 2005, the Morgan Hill City Council adopted an interim City Council policy that applies to
new development adjacent to streams and waterways:

         City Council Policy 05-02 - New development adjacent to streams and waterways shall be
          designed to preserve and integrate the waterways and associated habitats. New development
          should respect the water resource as an asset to the development, and shall not wall off the
          stream or waterway. New development shall incorporate open space buffers adjacent to
          waterways, in order to protect the stream and the existing/potential natural resources and
          habitats contained therein. Trails, pedestrian pathways and/or bikeways should be included
          within the open space buffer, either as reflected in the City's Park and Bikeways Master Plan
          or when reasonable and appropriate. Conditions of approval may be imposed to require
          restoration of riparian habitat, as feasible.

          This policy shall apply to land adjacent to streams and waterways which have value as
          natural and/or recreational resources, including Llagas, West Little Llagas, Edmundson,
          Fisher, Tennant, Corralitos and Coyote Creeks, as well as the Madrone and Butterfield
          Channels.

The proposed General Plan amendment would not result in a significant land use impact. (Less
Than Significant Impact)

Hale-Signature                                              57                                                     August 2009
4.11            NOISE

The following discussion of noise is based in part upon a noise analysis conducted by Illingworth &
Rodkin Inc., in August, 2001 for the MHCHS FEIR, as well as an environmental noise assessment
prepared by Illingworth & Rodkin Inc., in February, 2008 for the East Central-Urban Housing Initial
Study/Mitigated Negative Declaration (ECUH IS/MND).

4.11.1          Setting

4.11.1.1        Noise Background

Noise is defined as unwanted sound. Noise can be disturbing or annoying because of its pitch or
loudness. Pitch refers to relative frequency of vibrations, higher pitch signals sound louder to people.

A decibel (dB) is measured based on the relative amplitude of a sound. Ten on the decibel scale
marks the lowest sound level that a healthy, unimpaired human ear can detect. Sound levels in
decibels are calculated on a logarithmic basis such that each 10 decibel increase is perceived as a
doubling of loudness. The California A-weighted sound level, or dBA, gives greater weight to
sounds to which the human ear is most sensitive.

Sensitivity to noise increases during the evening and at night because excessive noise interferes with
the ability to sleep. Twenty-four hour descriptors have been developed that emphasize quiet-time
noise events. The Day/Night Average Sound Level, Ldn, is a measure of the cumulative noise
exposure in a community. It includes a 10 dB addition to noise levels from 10:00 PM to 7:00 AM to
account for human sensitivity to night noise.

4.11.1.2        Applicable Noise Standards

The City of Morgan Hill General Plan Acceptable Noise Levels standards state that the normally
acceptable interior noise level for residential uses is 45 dBA Ldn. General Plan Policy 7a states that
noise levels in new residential development exposed to an exterior Ldn of 60 dBA or greater should
be limited to maximum instantaneous noise levels (e.g., trucks on busy streets, train warning
whistles) in bedrooms of 50 dBA. Maximum instantaneous noise levels in all other habitable rooms
should not exceed 55 dBA. The maximum outdoor noise level for new residences near the railroad
shall be 70 dBA Ldn, recognizing that train noise is characterized by relatively few loud events. The
City's standards for acceptable exterior noise levels are 60 dBA Ldn in single-family residential use
areas and 70 dBA Ldn for playgrounds, neighborhood parks, agriculture and several types of outdoor
recreation. General Plan Policy 7a also states that where the City determines that providing an Ldn of
60 dBA or lower cannot be achieved after the application of reasonable and feasible mitigation, an
Ldn of 65 dBA may be permitted. In some cases, noise levels up to 75 dBA Ldn may be acceptable for
agriculture and outdoor recreation (such as golf courses and riding stables).

4.11.1.3        Existing Noise Environment

The project site is located at the urban edge of the City of Morgan Hill. The noise environment on
the site results primarily from vehicular traffic along Hale Avenue and Monterey Road, and railroad
activity on the tracks located on the eastern edge of the site. Based upon the future noise contour
map in the Morgan Hill General Plan, noise levels on most of the site in 2025 will be 70 dBA Ldn. A
small area in the northern portion of the site will be 65 dBA Ldn.



City of Morgan Hill                                                                         Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                    58                                        August 2009
Noise levels on the site were measured in 2001 for the MHCHS FEIR. Noise levels were monitored
over a 24-hour period at one location (LT-1) and in a 10-minute interval at another location (ST-1).
Refer to Figure 7 on the following page for the long- and short-term the noise measurement
locations.

The long-term measurement (LT-1) was taken approximately 309 feet from the center of Hale
Avenue and 510 feet from the center of Monterey Road, at the rear property line of residences on
Campoli Drive. The measured Ldn was 63 dBA. The predominant source of noise at this location
was vehicular traffic on both Hale Avenue and Monterey Road. This site was selected to quantify
the existing hourly distribution of noise levels at the property line of several residences south of the
project site. Noise generated by railroad activity also contributed to the measured noise levels.
Maximum noise levels ranged from 56 to 84 dBA. Hourly average noise levels (Leq) ranged from
about 43 to 63 dBA.

The short-term measurement (ST-1) was taken approximately 100 feet from the centerline of Hale
Avenue. The midday noise levels measured at this site was 55 dBA Leq.

Noise levels from railroad train operations were measured by Illingworth & Rodkin, Inc. in 1997
during preparation of the Lands of Madrone Ranch Noise Study for an adjacent development. Noise
levels were measured over a three-day period just south of Tilton Avenue at a distance of 75 feet
from the tracks. The daily average Ldn ranged from 72 dBA to 76 dBA over the three-day period.
The maximum noise levels generated by individual train passbys typically ranged from about 85 to
95 dBA. Occasionally, when trains sounded their warning horn immediately adjacent to the noise
monitoring station, the highest measured noise levels were 100 to 107 dBA. Trains typically sound
their warning horns within approximately one-quarter mile of at-grade railroad crossings. The
measured data described above are, therefore, applicable to the project site and represent what are
expected to be typical daily average and maximum noise levels resulting from railroad train activity.
The noise from the railroad trains would diminish at the rate of about six dBA with each doubling of
distance from the noise source, so a maximum noise level of 100 dBA measured at a distance of 75
feet from the railroad tracks would be reduced to about 80 dBA at a distance of 750 feet from the
railroad tracks.

In February 2008, an environmental noise assessment was prepared for the E. Central-Urban Housing
Initial Study/Mitigated Negative Declaration (ECUH IS/MND), which analyzed noise conditions on
a site located roughly 1.25 miles southeast of the project site. The ECUH IS/MND site is located
adjacent to the same UPRR tracks that border the eastern edge of the project site. Noise
measurements were taken at a location approximately 80 feet from the UPRR tracks at the terminus
of East Central Avenue. The estimated day-night average noise level at this location was measured
at 71 dBA Ldn, with maximum noise levels ranging from 85 to 95 dBA from train warning whistles.
On three occasions maximum noise levels ranged from 99 to 105 dBA. The relatively high
maximum noise levels were likely the result of a train sounding its whistle as it passed the site.
These noise levels correspond with those measured in 1997 at a similar distance from the UPRR
tracks.

4.11.1.4          Vibration Background

Ground vibration from passing trains consists of rapidly fluctuating motions or waves, which are also
measured in decibels. 10 The abbreviation "VdB" is used in this document for vibration decibels to

10
  Decibels of ground vibration refer to peak vertical velocities of the floors of affected structures. In contrast, sound
decibels refer to the time-averaged magnitudes of fluctuations in air pressure levels.

City of Morgan Hill                                                                                        Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                             59                                              August 2009

                                                                 RD
reduce confusion with sound decibels. Construction activities, train operations, and street traffic are
some of the most common external sources of vibration that can be perceptible inside residences.
Typical background vibration levels in residential areas are usually 50 VdB or lower, well below the
approximate 65 VdB threshold of perception for most people.

                                            Vibration Guidelines

Transit systems, including light and heavy rail, are potential sources of substantial ground vibration
depending on distance, the type and speed of trains, and the type of track. The Federal Transit
Administration (FTA) of the U.S Department of Transportation has developed vibration impact
assessment criteria for evaluating vibration impacts associated with transit projects.

According to the noise assessment prepared for the ECUH IS/MND, approximately 20 trains pass the
site on a daily basis. It is anticipated that rail traffic along the line will increase to 30 trains or more
per day with the planned Caltrain expansion project and other growth in rail service, but would not
exceed 70 trains per day. Train activity would be considered "occasional" with respect to the FTA
vibration impact criteria. For residences and buildings that experience "occasional events",
groundborne vibration of 75 VdB or less is acceptable.

4.11.1.5         Existing Vibration Environment

Railroad trains are a source of ground-borne vibration that could affect the project site. Vibration
measurements were made on February 5, 2008 for the ECUH IS/MND at two setback locations from
the UPRR tracks. The first measurements were taken approximately 80 feet from the railroad track
(V-1), and the second measurements were taken approximately 120 feet from the railroad track (V-
2). Vibration measurements were taken from each of the survey locations with two Caltrain trains
passing at approximately 30-35 mph. Location V-1 measured the passing trains at 76 VdB and 79
VdB, and Location V-2 measured the trains at 58 VdB and 61 VdB.

4.11.1.6         High-Speed Train

On November 4, 2008, California voters approved Proposition 1A, the "Safe, Reliable High-Speed
Passenger Train Bond Act", which will establish a high-speed train service linking Southern
California, the Sacramento San Joaquin Valley, and the San Francisco Bay Area. Among the
alignments being considered by the California High-Speed Rail Authority (CHSRA) for future high-
speed train routes is the existing UPRR alignment located adjacent to the project site. According to
the Draft Bay Area to Central Valley High-Speed Train (HST) Program EIR/EIS, 11 the proposed
high-speed train would use electrical power and operate in an exclusive right-of-way with no at-
grade crossings which would avoid the need to sound train horns during passbys near the project site.

According to the HST Program EIR/EIS, high-speed trains would travel at speeds of 125 miles per
hour or higher in the project area. The HST Program EIR/EIS indicates that noise levels from high-
speed trains traveling under 100 miles per hour would be comparable to the sounds of conventional
trains. At speeds above 150 miles per hour, high-speed train noise would increase over conventional
trains due to aerodynamic effects. Noise events from high-speed train passbys, however, would be
shorter in duration than noise events from conventional train passbys. Passbys of high-speed trains
would last a few seconds compared to 10-20 seconds for conventional passenger trains and over one
minute for freight trains. Groundborne vibration levels associated with high-speed train passbys are

11
  California High Speed Rail Authority and Federal Railroad Administration, Draft Bay Area to Central Valley
High-Speed Train (HST) Program EIR/EIS, Volume 1: Report, July 2007.

City of Morgan Hill                                                                                 Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                         61                                           August 2009
relatively lower than conventional trains due to advanced track technology, smooth track and wheel
surfaces, and high maintenance standards required for high-speed operation. The HST Program
EIR/EIS concluded that the utilization of the existing UPRR alignment adjacent to the site for the
high-speed train route would result in "Medium" noise and vibration impacts.

4.11.2.1        Impacts to the Proposed Project

The project proponent proposes a General Plan amendment to change the land use designation on the
site from Public Facilities to Single Family Medium (3-5 dwelling units per acre). This will allow
the future development of up to 150 single-family units on the site.




City of Morgan Hill                                                                                           Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                             62                                                 August 2009
                                             Interior Noise

The State of California Building Code and the City of Morgan Hill require that interior noise levels
within new residential units not exceed 45 dBA Ldn. The necessary attenuation required for future
residential development to meet the 45 dBA Ldn interior noise standard would require the practical
application of best available noise control methods such as stucco sided, staggered stud walls, high
performance windows, and individual heating and cooling systems so that windows may be kept
closed to control noise. Large windows and doors also should be oriented away from the railroad
where possible.

                                        Exterior Noise Levels

General Plan Policy 7a allows a maximum outdoor noise level for new residences near the railroad of
70 dBA Ldn.. Based on noise levels measured by Illingworth & Rodkin, Inc. for the Lands of
Madrone Ranch Noise Study and the ECUH IS/MND, portions of the project site closest to the
railroad tracks will be exposed to noise levels above 70 dBA Ldn..

Impact NOI-1: Future development of single family residences on portions of the site closest to the
railroad tracks would expose future residents to noise levels in excess of the guidelines established
for residential use in the City of Morgan Hill's General Plan. (Significant Impact)

                                       Groundborne Vibration

Vibration measurements made for the ECUH IS/MND at two setback locations from the UPRR
tracks measured passing trains at 76 VdB and 79 VdB at a distance of 80 feet and 58 VdB and 61
VdB at a distance of 120 feet. Any future residences located within 80 feet of the UPRR tracks
would be exposed to groundborne vibration in excess of the FTA's acceptable level of 75 Vdb for
"occasional events".

Impact NOI-2: Future development of single family residences within 80 feet of the UPRR tracks
would expose future residents to excessive groundborne vibration. (Significant Impact)

4.11.2.2        Impacts from the Proposed Project

                                            Project Traffic

The proposed General Plan amendment to allow up to 150 single-family residences on the site would
generate a maximum of approximately 1,510 daily trips, with 115 trips during the AM peak hour and
151 trips during the PM peak hour. Based on the traffic volumes of roadways surrounding the site
and the expected distribution of project trips (refer to Appendix A), this level of additional traffic
would increase day/night average noise levels in the vicinity of the site by less than 1 dBA. This
level of increase would not be measurable or perceptible. The increased number of vehicle trips to
and from the project site would not result in a significant increase in noise levels in the project area.

                        Possible Future Short-Term Construction Impacts

Construction activities generate considerable amounts of noise. Future construction of single family
residences could result in short term noise impacts. Construction-related noise levels are normally
highest during the site preparation phase and during the construction of infrastructure. Typical
hourly average construction generated noise levels are about 81 dBA to 88 dBA measured at a
distance of 50 feet during busy construction periods (e.g., earth moving equipment etc.).

City of Morgan Hill                                                                          Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                     63                                        August 2009
Construction-related noise levels are normally less during building erection, finishing, and
landscaping phases.

Impact NOI-3: Future construction of single family residences could result in short term noise
impacts. (Significant Impact)

4.11.2.3                Program Mitigation and Avoidance Measures

                                      Morgan Hill General Plan

Many of the policies in the City's General Plan were adopted for the purpose of avoiding or
mitigating environmental effects that could result from development planned within the City. All
future development is subject to General Plan policies, including the following, which will reduce or
avoid noise impacts:

       Noise Policy 7a  New development projects shall be designed and constructed to meet
        acceptable exterior noise level standards, as follows:

               The maximum exterior noise level of 60 dBA Ldn shall be applied in residential areas
                where outdoor use is a major consideration (e.g., backyards in single family housing
                developments and recreation areas in multi-family housing projects). Where the City
                determines that providing an Ldn of 60 dBA or lower cannot be achieved after the
                application of reasonable and feasible mitigation, an Ldn of 65 dBA may be
                permitted.
               Indoor noise levels should not exceed an Ldn of 45 dBA in new residential housing
                units.
               Noise levels in new residential development exposed to an exterior Ldn 60 dBA or
                greater should be limited to a maximum instantaneous noise level (e.g., trucks on
                busy streets, train warning whistles) in bedrooms of 50 dBA. Maximum
                instantaneous noise levels in all other habitable rooms should not exceed 55 dBA.
                The maximum outdoor noise level for new residences near the railroad shall be 70
                dBA Ldn, recognizing that train noise is characterized by relatively few loud events.

       Noise Policy 7b  The impact of a proposed development project on existing land uses should
        be evaluated in terms of the potential for adverse community response based on significant
        increase in existing noise levels, regardless of compatibility guidelines.

       Noise Policy 7e  Noise level increases resulting from traffic associated with new projects
        shall be considered significant if: a) the noise level increase is 5 dBA Ldn or greater, with a
        future noise level of less than 60 dBA Ldn, or b) the noise level increase is 3 dBA Ldn or
        greater, with a future noise level of 60 dBA Ldn or greater.

       Noise Policy 7g  Noise levels produced by other noise sources (such as ballfields) shall be
        considered significant if an acoustical study demonstrates they would substantially exceed
        ambient noise levels.

       Noise Policy 8a  Roadway design, traffic signalization and other traffic planning techniques
        (such as limiting truck traffic in residential areas) shall be used to reduce noise caused by
        speed or acceleration of vehicles.



City of Morgan Hill                                                                          Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                     64                                        August 2009
        Noise Policy 8b  If noise barriers are deemed the only effective mitigation for development
         along major transportation corridors, an acoustical analysis shall be conducted to determine
         necessary dimensions.

4.11.2.4        Measures to be Considered at the Time of Future Development

The following standard measures applied to development projects in the City of Morgan Hill could
be employed at the time of future development:

                                             Interior Noise

        Prior to the issuance of building permits, a detailed acoustical analysis, in conformance with
         California Noise Insulation Standards in Title 24, Part 2 of the California Code of regulations
         (California Building Code), will be required for final design of the proposed single-family
         residential uses. The project will incorporate sound control treatments to meet an interior Ldn
         of 45 dBA (or 50 dBA as applicable) or less (with the windows closed) to the satisfaction of
         the City Building Official.

        Prior to the issuance of building permits, a detailed vibration analysis, in conformance with
         the Federal Transit Administration (FTA) vibration criteria and to the satisfaction of the City
         Building Official, could be required for final design of the proposed single-family residential
         uses. The project will not construct housing in areas that would be exposed to groundborne
         vibration in excess of FTA's acceptable level of 75 Vdb for "occasional events".

                                             Exterior Noise

        Prior to the issuance of building permits, a detailed acoustical analysis, will be required for
         final design of the proposed single-family residential development. The exterior open space
         areas shall be designed to meet an exterior Ldn 70 dBA or less, such mitigation measures may
         include: using the residential buildings to provide shielding for outdoor use areas including
         courtyards, rear yards, side yards, etc; constructing sound walls; and/or increased setback
         distances from the railroad. The final details for these measures will be determined during
         development of the final site plan, prior to issuance of building permits.

                                          Construction Noise

        Under the Morgan Hill Municipal Code, allowed hours of construction are limited to avoid
         substantial impacts to sensitive receptors, such as nearby residents, as follows:

               Construction activities shall be limited to the hours between 7:00 AM to 8:00 PM on
                weekdays and 9:00 AM to 6:00 PM on Saturdays. There shall be no construction
                activities on Sundays or federal holidays (Municipal Code Chapter 8.28.040)

4.11.3          Conclusion

Implementation of the General Plan policies, standard measures, and measures to be considered at
the time of future development discussed above would reduce or avoid noise impacts at the time of
possible future development to a less than significant level. (Less Than Significant Impact With
Mitigation Incoporated)



City of Morgan Hill                                                                          Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                     65                                        August 2009
4.12               POPULATION AND HOUSING

4.12.1             Setting

According to California Department of Finance estimates, Morgan Hill's population for 2008 was
39,301 with 3.103 persons per households. 12 The Association of Bay Area Governments (ABAG)
projects the population for Morgan Hill to be 51,700 in 2030.13

As part of the General Plan, residential development within the City of Morgan Hill is controlled by
the Residential Development Control System (RDCS). By approving Measure C in 2004 and
Measure F in 2006, Morgan Hill voters extended the City's RDCS to 2020. RDCS establishes a
population ceiling for the City of 48,000 as of January 1, 2020.

Morgan Hill currently has a significant portion of its workforce traveling outside the City for
employment. Increasing jobs in the City would help to alleviate peak hour traffic by eliminating the
need for workers to commute from Morgan Hill to employment centers in northern Santa Clara
County.

The City's General Plan policies include maintaining a jobs housing balance (Jobs and Housing
Policy 2d). In 2005, the City had approximately 16,860 employed residents and 14,040 jobs or 0.83
jobs per employed resident.

4.12.2             Environmental Checklist and Discussion of Impacts
