4.12.2.1        Impacts from the Project

The project proponent proposes a General Plan amendment to change the land use designation on the
site from Public Facilities to Single Family Medium (3-5 dwelling units per acre). This will allow
the future development of up to 150 single-family units on the site.

The proposed General Plan amendment would allow residential development on the parcel. A
maximum of 150 dwelling units could be constructed on the project site under the proposed land use.
While the General Plan amendment would facilitate residential growth in Morgan Hill, residential
growth in Morgan Hill is ultimately controlled by the Residential Development Control System
(RDCS). By approving Measure C in 2004, Morgan Hill voters extended the City's RDCS to 2020.
The General Plan assumes that some form of residential growth control and the current allowed rate
of 250 new units per year will continue until 2020, with the end result being a city population of
48,000. For this reason, population growth over the planning period will be consistent with the
assumptions in the City of Morgan Hill General Plan.

Subdivision to allow the construction of residences is not currently proposed by the project. A future
subdivision would be subject to the City's RDCS process.

4.12.3          Conclusion

Possible future residential development of up to 150 residences would not foster a substantial
increase in population in the City of Morgan Hill above projected population levels. (Less Than
Significant Impact)




City of Morgan Hill                                                                       Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                    67                                      August 2009
4.13             PUBLIC SERVICES

4.13.1           Setting

4.13.1.1         Fire Service

The City of Morgan Hill contracts for fire and emergency medical services with the Santa Clara
County Fire Department. The City is served by the following two County fire stations: 1) El Toro
Fire Station, located at 18300 Old Monterey Road (approximately one mile southeast of the project
site), and 2) Dunne Hill Fire Station, located at 2100 East Dunne Avenue (approximately 4.5 miles
southeast of the project site). It is the Fire Department's goal to respond to calls within five and one-
half minutes. The City is also served under a mutual aid agreement by the California Department of
Forestry and Fire Protection (CDF). The CDF Station is located at 15670 South Monterey Road
(approximately three miles southeast of the project site).

4.13.1.2         Police Service

Police service is provided to the site by the City of Morgan Hill Police Department. The Morgan Hill
Police Facility is located at 16200 Vineyard Boulevard, just north of Tennant Avenue. The Police
Department's goal is to respond to Priority One calls within five minutes and Priority Two calls
within 10 minutes.

4.13.1.3         Schools

The project site is located within the Morgan Hill Unified School District. The District has nine
elementary schools, two middle schools, two comprehensive high schools, one continuation high
school, and a community adult school, as well as a home schooling program. The nearest schools to
the project site are Burnett Elementary (located approximately one mile northwest of the site),
Britton Middle School (located approximately 1.5 miles southeast of the site), and Sobrato High
School (located approximately one mile north of the site).

4.13.1.4         Parks

The City of Morgan Hill currently owns approximately 150 acres of parks and recreational facilities
including two community parks, two neighborhood parks, two neighborhood/school parks, and 14
mini-parks.

In addition to parks, the City owns special use recreational facilities. These facilities include the
Morgan Hill Aquatics Center, Centennial Recreation Center, Community and Cultural Center, and
Outdoor Sports Center. School facilities are also available for use after school hours and on
weekends.

Based on the current Draft Capital Improvements Program (CIP), the City will purchase 40 acres of
parkland in summer 2009 and the City will own a total of approximately 213 acres of parkland by the
end of 2011 to serve an estimated population of 41,391. 14 This exceeds the City's goal of five acres
of parkland per 1,000 capita.



14
  City of Morgan Hill, Projection of Developed Parkland per 1,000 Population, Based on Draft 09/10 - 11/12 CIP,
June 17, 2009.

City of Morgan Hill                                                                                 Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                         68                                           August 2009
Morgan Hill residents also utilize county and state parks. The closest facilities to the City are the
Anderson Reservoir to the east, the Coyote Creek park chain to the north, and Henry Coe State Park
to the east.

The City is also in the process of developing a Trails Master Plan, which is currently undergoing
CEQA environmental review. The Master Plan is intended to provide long-term direction for
guiding future trail development given the projected continued growth of Morgan Hill and the region.
The Master Plan is intended to be a flexible, comprehensive, and long-range planning document for
the acquisition of properties for a future citywide trails system. It is also intended to build upon the
Morgan Hill Bicycle Plan by identifying additional linkages, pathways, and commute routes for both
pedestrian and bicyclists, while acknowledging the surrounding natural environment. The Master
Plan proposes open space trails for the undeveloped hillsides in and around Morgan Hill, providing
access to open grassy ridges with panoramic views. These open space trails will also provide access
from Morgan Hill to nearby parks and existing trail connections.

4.13.2          Environmental Checklist and Discussion of Impacts

4.13.2.1        Fire and Police Service

Future residences would be constructed in conformance with current building and fire codes,
including features that would reduce potential fire hazards. Future project designs would be
reviewed by both the Santa Clara County Fire Department and the Morgan Hill Police Department to
ensure that it incorporates appropriate safety features to reduce fire hazards and criminal activity.

Future residential development on the site would be unlikely to substantially increase the demand for
fire and police protection, or require construction or expansion of fire or police facilities.



City of Morgan Hill                                                                                          Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                            69                                                 August 2009
4.13.2.2        Schools

Future residential development on the site would increase the population of the project area and,
therefore, would increase demand on local schools. Using the Morgan Hill Unified School District's
student generation rate of 0.72 students per new housing unit, the future development could generate
up to approximately 108 new students at full buildout. Prior to future development, the Morgan Hill
School District would review the proposed projects during the RDCS process and, at that time,
determine if existing school facilities are adequate to serve the proposed projects.

State Law (Government Code Section 65996) specifies an acceptable method of offsetting a project's
effect on the adequacy of school facilities is payment of a school impact fee prior to issuance of a
building permit. The school impact fees implementation of measures specified in Government Code
65996 would be used to offset project-related increase in student enrollment. Future development
projects would be required to comply with the school impact fee requirements of the Morgan Hill
Unified School District.

4.13.2.3        Parks

The proposed General Plan amendment would generate additional residents in the City of Morgan
Hill. In providing a private park/open space for future residents, a future development could lessen
the project's impact on public park facilities. However, the development of private parkland, does
not satisfy the City's goal of providing public parkland.

The City of Morgan Hill has adopted a parkland dedication/park land in-lieu fee ordinance
(Municipal Code Chapter 17.28) that requires parkland dedication or in-lieu fees for residential
developments. This ordinance requires residential developers to dedicate public parkland or pay in-
lieu fees, or both, to offset the demand for neighborhood parkland created by their housing
developments. The acreage of parkland or amount of the in-lieu fee required is based upon criteria
outlined in Chapter 17.28 of the City's Municipal Code. Future projects will be required to comply
with the City's parkland dedication or in-lieu fees for residential developments, which will avoid
significant impacts to the City's park facilities.

4.13.2.4                Program Mitigation and Avoidance Measures

                                     Morgan Hill General Plan

Many of the policies in the City's General Plan were adopted for the purpose of avoiding or
mitigating environmental effects that could result from development planned within the City. All
future development is subject to General Plan policies, including the following, which will reduce or
avoid public services impacts:

       Services Policy 16a  Maintain high standards of siting and design in the development of
        City facilities (e.g., parks, City offices, fire stations).

       Services Policy 16c  Identify public facility and service needs, and coordinate their
        development to minimize costs and support achievement of community goals. (SCJAP 5.00)

       Public Safety Policy 17a  Ensure police and fire staffing and facilities as necessary to
        provide adequate public safety protection.



City of Morgan Hill                                                                         Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                     70                                       August 2009
        Public Safety Policy 17b  Promote police and fire security considerations in all structures by
         ensuring that crime and fire prevention concepts are considered in development and design.

        Parks and Recreation Policy 18a  Recreational facilities and programs shall meet the needs
         of all Morgan Hill residents, including seniors, youth, and citizens with disabilities.

        Parks and Recreation Policy 18h  Parks and recreational facilities shall be designed to
         primarily meet community needs. Regional need may be a consideration in the planning and
         design of recreation facilities if there are long-term operations and maintenance benefits
         (such as facilities where regional tournaments may help off-set long-term operations costs)
         and/or meet other General Plan goals (such as economic development). Facilities that may
         meet regional needs shall be located and designed in such a way to minimize impact on
         residential neighborhoods.

        Parks and Recreation Policy 18i  Incorporate emergency services (fire and police) into the
         design review process for new parks, recreation facilities, and trails.

                            Standard Measures (Laws and Regulations)

Future residences would be constructed in conformance with current building and fire codes,
including features that would reduce potential fire hazards. Future project designs would be
reviewed by both the Santa Clara County Fire Department and the Morgan Hill Police Department to
ensure that it incorporates appropriate safety features to reduce fire hazards and criminal activity.

State Law (Government Code Section 65996) specifies an acceptable method of offsetting a project's
effect on the adequacy of school facilities is payment of a school impact fee prior to issuance of a
building permit. The school impact fees implementation of measures specified in Government Code
65996 would be used to offset project-related increase in student enrollment. Future development
projects would be required to comply with the school impact fee requirements of the Morgan Hill
Unified School District.

The City of Morgan Hill has adopted a parkland dedication/park land in-lieu fee ordinance
(Municipal Code Chapter 17.28) that requires parkland dedication or in-lieu fees for residential
developments. This ordinance requires residential developers to dedicate public parkland or pay in-
lieu fees, or both, to offset the demand for neighborhood parkland created by their housing
developments. The acreage of parkland or amount of the in-lieu fee required is based upon criteria
outlined in Chapter 17.28 of the City's Municipal Code. Future projects will be required to comply
with the City's parkland dedication or in-lieu fees for residential developments, which will avoid
significant impacts to the City's park facilities.

4.13.3          Conclusion

Implementation of the General Plan policies and standard measures discussed above would reduce or
avoid public services impacts at the time of possible future development to a less than significant
level. (Less Than Significant Impact)




City of Morgan Hill                                                                         Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                     71                                       August 2009
4.14                RECREATION

4.14.1              Setting

The City's General Plan has a parks and recreation goal to provide useful, accessible and high-
quality park, recreation and trail facilities and programs. Morgan Hill's General Plan goal for
parkland is five acres per 1,000 residents; however, in accordance with State laws regarding the level
of impact fees and maximum requirements for subdivisions, the Municipal Code requires three acres
of parkland per 1,000 residents. Efforts to achieve greater than 3.0 acres per 1,000 residents are
made through other means such as voluntary commitments, state grants, school parks, etc.

The City of Morgan Hill currently owns approximately 150 acres of public parkland, including
various park facilities (e.g., community parks, neighborhood parks, mini-parks, shared-school fields,
creek trail, and demonstration garden) and recreational facilities (e.g., Aquatics Center, Centennial
Recreation Center, and Outdoor Sports Center). Not included in this total are school facilities solely
owned by the School District. These facilities are typically available after hours and on weekends
and include 12 baseball/softball fields, nine soccer fields, two football fields, two tracks, and four
swimming pools.

Based on the current Draft Capital Improvements Program (CIP), the City will purchase 40 acres of
parkland in summer 2009 and the City will own a total of approximately 213 acres of parkland by the
end of 2011 to serve an estimated population of 41,391. 15 This exceeds the City's goal of five acres
of parkland per 1,000 capita.

4.14.2.1        Impacts from the Project

The project proponent proposes a General Plan amendment to change the land use designation on the
site from Public Facilities to Single Family Medium (3-5 dwelling units per acre). This will allow
the future development of up to 150 single-family units on the site.

Based on the average number of three persons per household, future residential development on the
site could generate up to 450 residents. Using the City's parkland goal of five acres per 1,000
residents, the future residential development projects would need to provide 2.25 acres of public
parkland.

The City of Morgan Hill has adopted a parkland dedication/park land in-lieu fee ordinance
(Municipal Code Chapter 17.28) that requires parkland dedication or payment of in-lieu fees to
reduce the impact of residential developments on the City's public park system. The acreage of
parkland or amount of the in-lieu fee required is outlined in Chapter 17.28 of the City's Municipal
Code. Future residential development projects would be required to comply with the City's parkland
dedication/park land in-lieu fee ordinance. For this reason, the proposed project General Plan
amendment would not significantly impact parks or recreational facilities in the project area.

4.14.2.2        Program Mitigation and Avoidance Measures

                                    Morgan Hill General Plan

Many of the policies in the City's General Plan were adopted for the purpose of avoiding or
mitigating environmental effects that could result from development planned within the City. All
future development is subject to General Plan policies, including the following, which will reduce or
avoid recreation impacts:

       Services Policy 16a  Maintain high standards of siting and design in the development of
        City facilities (e.g., parks, City offices, fire stations).

       Services Policy 16c  Identify public facility and service needs, and coordinate their
        development to minimize costs and support achievement of community goals. (SCJAP 5.00)

       Parks and Recreation Policy 18a  Recreational facilities and programs shall meet the needs
        of all Morgan Hill residents, including seniors, youth, and citizens with disabilities.

       Parks and Recreation Policy 18h  Parks and recreational facilities shall be designed to
        primarily meet community needs. Regional need may be a consideration in the planning and
        design of recreation facilities if there are long-term operations and maintenance benefits
        (such as facilities where regional tournaments may help off-set long-term operations costs)
        and/or meet other General Plan goals (such as economic development). Facilities that may
        meet regional needs shall be located and designed in such a way to minimize impact on
        residential neighborhoods.

       Parks and Recreation Policy 18i  Incorporate emergency services (fire and police) into the
        design review process for new parks, recreation facilities, and trails.

                           Standard Measures (Laws and Regulations)

The City of Morgan Hill has adopted a parkland dedication/park land in-lieu fee ordinance
(Municipal Code Chapter 17.28) that requires parkland dedication or in-lieu fees for residential
developments. This ordinance requires residential developers to dedicate public parkland or pay in-
lieu fees, or both, to offset the demand for neighborhood parkland created by their housing
developments. The acreage of parkland or amount of the in-lieu fee required is based upon criteria
outlined in Chapter 17.28 of the City's Municipal Code. Future projects will be required to comply
with the City's parkland dedication or in-lieu fees for residential developments, which will avoid
significant impacts to the City's park facilities.

4.15            TRANSPORTATION

The following discussion is based upon a Transportation Impact Analysis prepared by Fehr and Peers
in June 2009. A copy of the analysis is provided in Appendix A of this Initial Study.

4.15.1          Setting

4.15.1.1        Regional and Local Roadway Access

The regional and local roadway network providing access to the site is described below and shown in
Figure 8. The eight study intersection locations are also shown on Figure 8 and discussed in Section
4.15.1.6.

US 101 is a north-south freeway that serves as the primary connection between Morgan Hill and all
other areas of Santa Clara County. US 101 extends north to San Francisco and south to Los Angeles.
The freeway has six lanes (three mixed-flow lanes in each direction) within Morgan Hill. North of
Cochrane Road, US 101 widens to eight lanes including three mixed-flow lanes and one high
occupancy vehicle (HOV) lane in each direction. HOV lanes, also known as diamond or carpool
lanes, restrict use to vehicles with two or more persons (carpool, vanpool, and buses) or motorcycles
during the morning (5:00 AM to 9:00 AM) and evening (3:00 PM to 7:00 PM) commute periods.
The Cochrane Road interchange provides primary access to the project site.

Monterey Road, through Morgan Hill, is generally a four-lane arterial roadway with separate left-turn
lanes at intersections and on-street parking in some areas. Monterey Road extends from San Jose
through the downtown area of Morgan Hill to the City of Gilroy. The speed limit on Monterey Road
varies from 45 miles per hour (mph) north of Cochrane Road to 25 mph between Main Avenue and
East Dunne Avenue in downtown. Several sets of speed lumps slow traffic through the downtown
area.

Cochrane Road is an arterial roadway that extends from Monterey Road east to Anderson Lake.
Cochrane Road is a two to six-lane facility that provides an interchange with US 101 at the north end
of the city. The posted speed limit is 45 mph.

Madrone Parkway is a two-lane undivided collector that extends eastward from its intersection with
Monterey Road and connects with Cochrane Road. The roadway is posted at 35 mph. Per the City's
July 2001 General Plan, Madrone Parkway will be extended westward to provide a connection
between Monterey Road and Hale Avenue. This extension is assumed in the 2030 roadway network.

Hale Avenue is generally a two-lane arterial extending north from its terminus at Main Avenue
towards San Jos, where it becomes Santa Teresa Boulevard. Near the project site, Hale Avenue
serves as a north-south commute corridor.

Llagas Road is a collector that extends eastward from the City's western city limits to Old Monterey
Road. The posted speed limit is 25 mph. Between Old Monterey Road and Llagas Creek Drive, the
roadway is a two-lane road that provides left-turn lanes into the intersecting local streets. West of
Llagas Creek Drive, Llagas Road is a two-lane facility.

Tilton Avenue is two-lane collector road that provides a connection between Hale Avenue and
Monterey Road. The posted speed limit is 35 mph.

                                                                                                                                                                                      Figure 1
4.15.1.2        Existing Transit Service

Bus service in Santa Clara County is operated by the Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority
(VTA). Commuter rail service (Caltrain) is provided from San Francisco to Gilroy by the Peninsula
Joint Powers Authority Board. Existing bus routes and Caltrain service are described below and
shown graphically on Figure 9.

                                           VTA Bus Routes

Route 16, a local community bus, provides service between the Morgan Hill Civic Center and
Burnett Avenue. Service operates every 60 minutes from 6:30 AM to 6:00 PM on weekdays only.

Route 68, a regional bus route, provides service between the City of Gilroy Caltrain/Greyhound
Station and the San Jose Diridon Caltrain Station. Service operates on weekdays every 30 minutes
from 4:15 AM to 1:20 AM and on weekends every 30 minutes from 5:45 AM to 1:20 AM.

                                           Caltrain Service

Caltrain provides frequent daily train service between San Jose and San Francisco. Service extends
south to Gilroy through Morgan Hill during commute periods, with three northbound trips during the
AM peak period and three southbound trips during the PM peak period stopping at the Morgan Hill
Caltrain Station. The Morgan Hill Caltrain Station is located east of Depot Street between First and
Second Streets, approximately two miles southeast of the project site.

4.15.1.3        Existing Pedestrian and Bicycle Facilities

Pedestrian facilities include sidewalks, crosswalks, pedestrian signals, and off-street paths that are
meant to provide safe and convenient routes for pedestrians to access destinations such as
institutions, businesses, public transportation, and recreation facilities. Crosswalks are not provided
on Tilton Avenue/Hale Avenue and Monterey Road/Tilton Avenue. Other study intersections
provide limited crosswalks in each direction to bring continuity with adjacent sidewalks. Sidewalk
facilities are provided on the following roadway segments within the vicinity of the project.

       Eastside of Hale Avenue between Tilton Avenue and northern end of the project site;
       Llagas Road between Hale Avenue and Old Monterey Avenue;
       Westside of Old Monterey Avenue between Llagas Road and Monterey Road;
       Eastside of Monterey Road between Cochrane Road and Old Monterey Road;
       Discontinuous segments along Monterey Road between Tilton Avenue and Cochrane Road.

Bicycle facilities comprise paths (Class I), lanes (Class II), and routes (Class III). Bicycle paths are
paved trails that are separate from roadways. Bicycle lanes are lanes on roadways designated for
bicycle use by striping, pavement legends, and signs. Bicycle routes are roadways designated for
bicycle use by signs only.

No Class I bike paths exist in the project vicinity. Class II bike lanes are located along the following
roadways in the study area:

       Monterey Road north of Cochrane Road;
       Monterey Road south of Old Monterey Road;
       Cochrane Road between Monterey Road and Sutter Boulevard;

4.15.1.4           Intersection Level of Service Methodology

The operations of roadway facilities are described in terms of level of service (LOS). LOS is a
qualitative description of traffic flow based on such factors as speed, travel time, delay, and freedom
to maneuver. Six levels are defined from LOS A, with the best operating conditions, to LOS F, with
the worst operating conditions. LOS E represents "at-capacity" operations. Operations are
designated as LOS F when volumes exceed capacity, resulting in stop-and-go conditions.

The level of service method for signalized intersections approved by the City of Morgan Hill and
VTA analyzes intersection operations based on average control vehicular delay, as described in
Chapter 16 of the 2000 Highway Capacity Manual (HCM) by the Transportation Research Board,
with adjusted saturation flow rates to reflect conditions in Santa Clara County. Control delay
includes initial deceleration delay, queue move-up time, stopped delay, and final acceleration delay.
The average control delay for signalized intersections is calculated using TRAFFIX analysis software
and is correlated to a LOS designation as shown in Table 4.15-1.

                                             Table 4.15-1:
                          Signalized Intersection Level of Service Definitions
                               Using Average Control Vehicular Delay
                                                                                      Average
            Level
                                                                                   Control Delay
             of                             Description
                                                                                    per Vehicle
           Service
                                                                                     (seconds)
                      Operations with very low delay occurring with                     10.0
             A
                      favorable progression and/or short cycle lengths
              B+      Operations with low delay occurring with good                  10.1 to 12.0
              B       progression and/or short cycle lengths.                        12.1 to 18.0
              B-                                                                     18.1 to 20.0
              C+      Operations with average delays resulting from fair             20.1 to 23.0
              C       progression and/or longer cycle lengths. Individual            23.1 to 32.0
              C-      cycle failures begin to appear.                                32.1 to 35.0
                      Operations with longer delays due to a combination             35.1 to 39.0
              D+
                      of unfavorable progression, long cycle lengths, and            39.1 to 51.0
              D
                      high V/C ratios. Many vehicles stop and individual             51.1 to 55.0
              D-
                      cycle failures are noticeable.
              E+      Operations with high delay valued indicating poor              55.1 to 60.0
              E       progression, long cycle lengths, and high V/C ratios.          60.1 to 75.0
              E-      Individual cycle failures are frequent occurrences.            75.1 to 80.0
                      Operations with delays unacceptable to most drivers              > 80.0
              F       occurring due to over-saturation, poor progression, or
                      very long cycle lengths.
           Source: VTA's Congestion Management Program (CMP) Traffic Level of Service Analysis
           Guidelines, June 2003, and Transportation Research Board, Highway Capacity Manual, 2000.

BICYCLE FACILITIES                                                                                                                                                          FIGURE 10
                                                                                                                                                       Existing Bicycle Facilities
                                                                                                                                                                                    Figure 2
Operations of the unsignalized study intersections are evaluated using the method contained in
Chapter 17 of the 2000 HCM and calculated using TRAFFIX analysis software. LOS ratings for
stop-sign controlled intersections are based on the average control delay expressed in seconds per
vehicle. At two-way or side-street-stop controlled intersections, control delay is calculated for each
movement, not for the intersection as a whole. For approaches composed of a single lane, delay is
computed as the average of all movements in that lane. For all-way stop-controlled locations, a
weighted average delay for the entire intersection is presented. Table 4.15-2 summarizes the
relationship between delay and LOS for unsignalized intersections.

                                             Table 4.15-2:
                         Unsignalized Intersection Level of Service Definitions
                                                                                        Average Control
  Level of
                                            Description                                 Delay Per Vehicle
  Service
                                                                                            (Seconds)
      A                                 Little or no delay.                                    10.0
      B                                Short traffic delays.                               10.1 to 15.0
      C                              Average traffic delays.                               15.1 to 25.0
      D                                Long traffic delays.                                25.1 to 35.0
      E                             Very long traffic delays.                              35.1 to 50.0
      F            Extreme traffic delays with intersection capacity exceeded.                > 50.0
Source: Transportation Research Board, Highway Capacity Manual, 2000.

The City of Morgan Hill has established a minimum acceptable operating level of LOS D+ for
signalized intersections and LOS D for unsignalized intersections. Per the City of Morgan Hill
General Plan, the Madrone Parkway/Monterey Road study intersection is one of three signalized
intersections in the City that are allowed to operate at LOS D.

4.15.1.5        Freeway Segment Level of Service Methodology

Freeway segments are evaluated using VTA's analysis procedure, which is based on the density of
the traffic flow using methods described in the 2000 HCM. Density is expressed in passenger cars
per mile per lane. The Congestion Management Program range of densities for freeway segment
level of service is shown in Table 4.15-3. The LOS standard for the freeway segments is LOS E.

                                            Table 4.15-3:
                               Freeway Segment Level of Service Definitions
                  Level of Service                            Density (passenger cars per mile per lane)
                         A                                                       11
                         B                                                   11.1 to 18.0
                         C                                                   18.1 to 26.0
                         D                                                   26.1 to 46.0
                         E                                                   46.1 to 58.0
                         F                                                     > 58.0
Sources: Traffic Level of Service Analysis Guidelines, VTA Congestion Management Program, June 2003; Highway
Capacity Manual, Transportation Research Board, 2000.

4.15.2.1           Thresholds of Significance

                                               Signalized Intersections

For the purposes of this analysis, a significant traffic impact at a signalized intersection would occur
if the addition of project traffic causes:

          Intersection operations to deteriorate from an acceptable level (LOS D+ or better for most
           intersections and LOS D or better for the Madrone Parkway/Monterey Road intersection)
           under the Existing Conditions to an unacceptable level ( LOS D or worse for most
           intersections and LOS D- or worse for the Madrone Parkway/Monterey Road intersection);
           or,
          Exacerbation of unacceptable operations under Existing Conditions by increasing the average
           critical delay by more than 4 seconds and increasing the critical volume-to-capacity (V/C)
           ratio by 0.01 or more at an intersection operating at LOS E or LOS F under 2030 General
           Plan Baseline with Project Conditions.
None of the intersections analyzed for this report are designated Congestion Management Program
(CMP) intersections.

                                           Unsignalized Intersections

Level of service analysis at unsignalized intersections is generally used to determine the need for
modification in type of intersection control (i.e. all-way stop or signalization). As part of this
evaluation traffic volumes, delay, and traffic signal warrants are evaluated to determine if the
existing intersection control is appropriate.

The City has generally used a minimum acceptable operating level of LOS D for unsignalized
intersections. In accordance with the City's adopted thresholds of significance (in its May 2008
Guidelines for Preparing Transportation Impact Reports), significant impacts are defined to occur
when the addition of project traffic causes the worst movement/approach to degrade to LOS E or
LOS F and the intersection satisfies the peak hour signal warrants from the MUTCD.




City of Morgan Hill                                                                                               Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                                 84                                                 August 2009
                                         Freeway Segments

According to VTA's Transportation Impact Analysis Guidelines, a freeway segment analysis should
be included if the project meets one of the following requirements:

       The proposed development project is expected to add traffic equal to at least one percent of a
        freeway segment's capacity.

       The proposed development project is adjacent to one of the freeway segment's access or
        egress points

       Based on engineering judgment, Lead Agency staff determines that the freeway segment
        should be included in the analysis.

According to CMP guidelines, freeway segments with project traffic equal to or greater than one
percent of the freeway segment's capacity must be evaluated. For mixed-flow lanes, freeway
segment capacities are defined as 2,200 vehicles per hour per lane (vphpl) for four-lane freeway
segments and 2,300 vphpl for six-lane freeway segments. HOV lane capacities are defined between
1,800 to 1,900 vphpl.

If a project meets the criteria outlined above, then the implementation of the proposed project could
result in a significant impact if the addition of project traffic on a freeway segment exceeded one of
the following thresholds:

       The addition of project traffic causes the operating level of a freeway segment to deteriorate
        from LOS E or better under Existing Conditions to LOS F; or

       The number of new trips added by a proposed project to a segment already operating at LOS
        F under Existing Conditions is more than one percent of the freeway segment capacity.

4.15.2.2        2030 General Plan Conditions

This discussion describes the expected traffic operations under 2030 General Plan Conditions with
and without the proposed GPA. The City of Morgan Hill travel demand forecasting model was used
to estimate 2030 traffic volumes. 2030 land use and network assumptions are briefly discussed
below and followed by a more detailed discussion of intersection operations.

                       Land Use and Transportation Network Assumptions

The City's travel demand forecasting model was used to develop 2030 General Plan traffic volume
estimates. 2030 land use estimates were based on input from City staff and regionally approved data
from the Association of Bay Area Governments (ABAG). Under 2030 General Plan Baseline
Conditions the model includes agricultural land uses for the project site. To present a more
conservative approach, project trips associated with the GPA were added to the 2030 General Plan
Baseline volumes and no trip credits were taken for the agricultural uses modeled for the site.
Included in the model is the planned roadway network based on the 2001 General Plan Circulation
Element. Planned roadway network improvements relevant to the project include:

       Construction of the Madrone Parkway as a four lane roadway extension between Monterey
        Road and Hale Avenue bisecting the project property;


City of Morgan Hill                                                                         Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                    85                                        August 2009
         Construction of the Llagas Creek Drive as a two lane collector between Hale Avenue and
          Monterey Road;
         Widening of Hale Avenue from two to four lanes from Tilton Avenue to Main Street;
         Widening of Monterey Road from four to six lanes north of Cochrane Road;
         Widening of Monterey Road from two to four lanes south of Cochrane Road; and
         Widening of Cochrane Road from four to six lanes east of Monterey Road.

                  2030 General Plan Baseline with Project Traffic Volume Estimates

The amount of traffic associated with the project was estimated using a three-step process: (1) trip
generation, (2) trip distribution, and (3) trip assignment. In the first step, the amount of traffic
entering and exiting the project area was estimated on a daily and peak-hour basis. In the second
step, the direction vehicles use to approach and depart the site was estimated. The trips were
assigned to specific street segments and intersection turning movements in the third step and added to
the 2030 General Plan Baseline traffic volumes to develop 2030 General Plan Baseline with Project
traffic volumes. The results of the process for this analysis are described in the following sections.

Trip Generation

The proposed GPA allows for the development of up to 150 single family homes on the 30-acre
project site. Trip generation was calculated using rates from the Institute of Transportation Engineers
(ITE) Trip Generation (8th Edition). The peak-hour trip generation trip estimates for each phase are
presented in Table 4.15-6. A 150 single family home development is estimated to generate 1,510
daily trips, 115 AM peak-hour trips (29 inbound and 86 outbound), and 151 PM peak-hour trips (95
inbound and 56 outbound).

                                             Table 4.15-6:
                              Project Trip Generation Rates and Estimates
              Size         Daily             AM Peak-Hour                   PM Peak-Hour
    Use
             (d.u.)2        1
                        Rate Trips Rate    1
                                               In     Out    Total   Rate 1
                                                                              In   Out   Total
 Single
 Family
               150      10.07     1,510     0.77       29       86        115         1.01   95   56       151
Dwelling
  Units
Notes:
1
  Rate per dwelling unit
2
  d.u. = dwelling unit
3
  Daily, AM, and PM peak hour trip generation rates based on fitted curve.
Source: Trip Generation, 8th Edition, Institute of Transportation Engineers (2008).

Trip Distribution

Project trip distribution was primarily based on a select zone analysis using the City's travel demand
forecasting model. Location of supporting land uses in the vicinity of the project area, information
from previous traffic studies in the area, and input from City staff was used to refine the trip
distribution. Approximately 40 percent of trips are expected to travel north of the City of Morgan
Hill and 25 percent to destinations south of the City. The remaining trips are spread to destinations
within the City of Morgan Hill.




City of Morgan Hill                                                                               Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                            86                                      August 2009
     Trip Assignment

     Trips generated by the proposed project were assigned to the roadway system based on the directions
     of approach and departure described above. Project-generated trips were added to the 2030 General
     Plan Baseline volumes to estimate volumes under 2030 General Plan Baseline with Project
     Conditions.

                                   2030 General Plan Intersection Level of Service

     Existing intersection configurations were modified to accommodate the proposed Madrone Parkway
     extension crossing between Monterey Road and Hale Avenue and widened roadways (e.g. Monterey
     Road widened from two to four lanes south of Cochrane Road and Hale Avenue widened from two to
     four lanes between Tilton Avenue and Main Street).

     2030 General Plan roadway intersection lane configurations, signal timings, and peak-hour turning
     movement volumes were used as inputs for the LOS calculations. The results of the LOS analysis
     for 2030 General Plan with Project Conditions are presented in Table 4.15-7, below. Measured
     against the City's current LOS D+ standard for signalized intersections (LOS D is acceptable for the
     Madrone Parkway/Monterey Road intersection) and LOS D standard for unsignalized intersections,
     all of the study intersection would operate at acceptable levels.

                                  2030 General Plan Signal Warrant Analysis

     The unsignalized Hilton Avenue/Tilton Avenue intersection is projected to operate at acceptable
     levels in 2030, and no signal warrant analysis was performed.

                                2030 General Plan Freeway Segment Analysis

     According to CMP guidelines, freeway segments to which a proposed development is projected to
     add trips equal to or greater than one percent of the freeway segment's capacity must be evaluated.
     The freeway segments immediately north and south of Cochrane Road were reviewed to determine if
     a significant amount of project traffic would be added to these freeway segments. Capacities of
     2,300 vehicles per hour per lane (vphpl) for freeway segments with three or more lanes and
     capacities of 2,200 vphpl for freeway segments with two lanes were used in the freeway analysis. To
     be conservative, no project trips were assigned to HOV lanes.

     Table 4.15-8, below, outlines the estimated number of net new trips added to the freeway segments
     under 2030 General Plan with Project Conditions. The proposed project would not add new trips
     greater than one percent of the freeway segment capacity to any of the study freeway segments.
     Therefore, no additional freeway segment analysis is required for the proposed project and the
     project would not result in a significant impact to freeways.

                                    Pedestrian, Bicycle, and Transit Impacts

     The City's Guidelines for Preparation of Transportation Impact Reports does not specify impact
     criteria for pedestrian, bicycle, and transit impacts. However, these impacts are generally evaluated
     based on whether a proposed project would: 1) conflict with existing or planned pedestrian, bicycle,
     or transit facilities, or 2) create walking, bicycling, or transit use demand without providing adequate
     and appropriate facilities for non-motorized mobility.




     City of Morgan Hill                                                                                Initial Study

The proposed project is not expected to increase the biking, or transit demand to a level where it
could not be accommodated by existing or planned facilities. To accommodate pedestrian travel,
development of the project site should include the construction of sidewalks on Hale Avenue along
the project frontage. On the east side of the project site, the existing rail road tracks provide a barrier
to Monterey Road. Under a porposed General Plan Circulation Element Amendment now under
study by the City of Morgan Hill, the construction of the Madrone Parkway extension would change
to a two-lane roadway and include an underpass at Monterey Road and the railroad tracks. This grade
separation project should provide adequate pedestrian and bicycle access to facilitate connectivity
between the proposed and existing residential developments west of Monterey Road and the land
uses to the east. With the provision of sidewalks on Hale Avenue along the project frontage at the
time of future development, the proposed implementation of the General Plan amendment would
have a less than significant impact on pedestrian, bicycle, and transit facilities and services.

4.15.2.3          2030 General Plan Cumulative Conditions

This discussion describes the expected traffic operations under 2030 Conditions with all of the
proposed General Plan amendments in place. This scenario includes model-recommended roadway
traffic volumes plus vehicle trips generated by pending General Plan amendment land uses (including
the proposed project), as well as changes in travel patterns caused by City-proposed General Plan
amendment roadway network changes. The City`s travel demand forecasting model was used to
estimate 2030 General Plan Cumulative Condition traffic volumes. The proposed General Plan
amendment land use and network assumptions are briefly discussed and followed by a more detailed
discussion of the resulting intersection operations.

                 Land Use and Transportation Network General Plan Amendments

The City's travel demand forecasting model was used to develop 2030 General Plan Cumulative
traffic volume estimates. The 2030 General Plan Cumulative model includes all information from
2030 General Plan Baseline Conditions, plus changes in the land uses and roadway network based on
information from the eight pending General Plan amendments. In addition to the Hale-Signature


City of Morgan Hill                                                                           Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                              89                                August 2009
property General Plan amendment analyzed for the report, the following General Plan amendments
are included in the 2030 General Plan Cumulative Conditions' model:

       DeWitt-West Hills Community Church: Add parcels totaling 8.7 acres into the Urban Service
        Area and replace approximately 11,600 s.f. of church and school space with approximately
        20,000 s.f. of the same land use.

       Peet  Trumpp: Add 6 acres of single family residences on the west side of Peet Road and
        north of Half Road into the Urban Service Area.

       Monterey-Morgan Hill Bible Church: Add parcels totaling 8.7 acres into the Urban Service
        Area and replace approximately 11,600 s.f. of church and school space with approximately
        20,000 s.f. of the same land use.

       Watsonville-Royal Oaks Enterprises: Change one parcel from Single Family Medium (3-5
        du/ac) to Light Commercial/Residential on 8.19 acres at the southwest corner of Watsonville
        Road and Monterey Road, and change a second parcel from Single Family Medium to Multi-
        Family Medium (14-21 du/ac) on 7.5 acres on the Watsonville Road, west of Monterey Road.

       Walnut Grove Extension Realignment/Simonsen  DeRose Applications: Amend General
        Plan Land Use Designation from Multi-Family Low and Commercial to 100 percent
        Commercial. The anticipated square footage for the development will be approximately
        113,500 s.f.

       Butterfield-Berg & Berg: The proposed General Plan amendment will amend approximately
        56 acres of Industrial to a combination of Commercial and Multi-Family Low, Multi-Family
        Medium, and the new Single Family High (5-10 du/acre) land use designation the City is
        creating in conjunction with its 2009 Housing Element Update. The proposed land uses
        include approximately 446 small-lot single family residential units (which may be "senior
        housing" but which are analyzed as standard housing units), about 60 apartment units, and
        about 25,000 square feet of retail commercial uses. This project is generally bounded by the
        Union Pacific Railroad tracks to the west, Jarvis Drive to the north, Sutter Boulevard to the
        south, Butterfield Boulevard to the east.

       Downtown Specific Plan: This amendment also includes Downtown Redevelopment, Dunne
        Avenue/Depot Street. This application proposes to redevelop the Downtown area with
        approximately 1,204 residential units and approximately 186,000 s.f. of retail space relative
        to existing uses. The Downtown area is generally bounded by Depot Street on the east,
        Dunne Avenue on the south, Del Monte Street on the west and Main Avenue on the north.

In addition to the network changes based on the pending General Plan amendments, the 2030
General Plan Cumulative roadway network includes the "Model-Recommended Roadway Capacity
General Plan Amendments" and City-initiated roadway network amendments. Compared to the
network assumption under 2030 General Plan Baseline Conditions, the following roadway network
differences are relevant to the proposed project and study locations:

       Hale Avenue will be maintained as a two lane road and will not be widened to four lanes

       Madrone Parkway extension will be constructed as a two lane road instead of four lanes



City of Morgan Hill                                                                       Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                    90                                      August 2009
All other network assumptions from the 2030 General Plan Baseline Conditions that are directly
applicable to the study intersection remain in effect.

                Cumulative General Plan Amendment Intersection Levels of Service

2030 General Plan Cumulative intersection lane configurations, signal timings, and peak-hour
turning movement volumes were used as inputs for the LOS calculations. The results of the LOS
analysis for 2030 General Plan Cumulative Conditions are presented in Table 4.15-9. Measured
against the 2001 General Plan Circulation Element LOS standards, the following study intersection
will operate unacceptably under this scenario:

        Hale Avenue/Tilton Avenue  This all-way stop controlled intersection will operate at LOS E
         with an average delay of 42.2 seconds during the AM peak period. The northbound approach
         would operate at LOS F and the southbound and westbound approaches would operate at
         LOS B or better.


                                            Table 4.15-9:
                 2030 General Plan Cumulative Conditions Intersection Levels of Service

                                                                                                                    Signal

  Whole intersection weighted average control delay expressed in seconds per vehicle calculated using methods described

  LOS = Level of service. LOS calculations conducted using the TRAFFIX level of service analysis software package.

  Peak hour signal warrant analysis completed for unacceptable unsignalized intersection operations. N/A = signalized

City of Morgan Hill                                                                                      Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                            91                                             August 2009
The signalized Monterey Road/Madrone Parkway intersection would operate at LOS D with 41.7
second of average intersection delay during the morning peak period. This intersection is one of
three signalized intersections that the City's LOS standards allows to operate at LOS D (up to 55
seconds of delay); therefore this intersection would operate acceptably. The remaining six study
intersections are projected to operate at acceptable LOS D+ or better.

                 Cumulative General Plan Amendment Signal Warrant Analysis

The peak-hour signal warrant from the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) was
evaluated for the unsignalized intersection that is projected to operate unacceptably under 2030
General Plan Cumulative Conditions to determine if a traffic signal is warranted. Under this
scenario, the Hale Avenue/Tilton Avenue intersection would operate at unacceptable LOS E with
42.2 seconds of delay during the morning peak hour and at acceptable LOS C during the evening
peak hour. The result of the peak-hour warrant analysis indicates that the intersection does not
satisfy the peak hour warrant analysis (refer to Appendix A).

            Cumulative General Plan Amendment Intersection Operations Summary

Based on the City of Morgan Hill's LOS standards and adopted thresholds of significance, none of
the study intersections are projected to be significantly impacted by the proposed project. Thus, no
intersection mitigation measures are required.

The unsignalized Hale Avenue/Tilton Avenue intersection is expected to operate at unacceptable
levels during the AM peak hour. However, this intersection would not meet the Peak Hour Warrant
for traffic signal installation during either peak period. Based on the City's adopted thresholds of
significance for impact criteria, this intersection would not be considered to have a significant
cumulative impact and signalization would not be required.

4.15.3          Conclusion

The proposed implementation of the General Plan Amendment would not result in significant
impacts to the transportation system. (Less Than Significant Impact)




City of Morgan Hill                                                                       Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                    92                                      August 2009
4.16            UTILITIES AND SERVICE SYSTEMS

4.16.1          Setting

4.16.1.1        Water Service

The City of Morgan Hill provides potable water service to its residential, commercial, industrial, and
institutional customers within the City limits. The City's water system facilities include 14
groundwater wells, 10 potable water storage tanks, 10 booster stations, and over 160 miles of
pressured pipes ranging from two to 14 inches in diameter. There is an existing 10-inch or greater
water main in Monterey Road. 16

4.16.1.2        Sanitary Sewer Service

The City of Morgan Hill sewer collection system consists of approximately 135 miles of six-inch
through 30-inch diameter sewers, and includes 15 sewage lift stations and associated force mains.
The system also consists of trunk sewers, which are generally 12 inches in diameter and larger, that
convey the collected wastewater flows through an outfall that continues south to the Wastewater
Treatment Facility (WWTF) in Gilroy. The WWTF is jointly owned by the cities of Gilroy and
Morgan Hill. The City's existing sewer collection system meets the needs of existing customers.
The City has planned and constructed sewer facilities in conjunction with new street construction in
anticipation of future growth and sewage needs. There is an existing 15-inch sewer line in Monterey
Road. 17

4.16.1.3        Storm Drainage

The City of Morgan Hill's storm drainage system consists of a combination of curb and gutter
facilities, curb inlets, underground pipelines, and bubblers that drain into detention basins or to the
nearest creek. Creeks within the City of Morgan Hill flow to either Monterey Bay or San Francisco
Bay. Storm water runoff from the project site and surrounding area is released into Fisher Creek,
which drains to the San Francisco Bay. 18 An existing storm drainage pipeline is located on the
southeastern border of the site.

4.16.1.4        Other Services

South Valley Disposal & Recycling, Inc. (SVDR) provides solid waste and recycling services to the
businesses and residents of the cities of Morgan Hill and Gilroy and the surrounding Unincorporated
Southern Santa Clara County. South Valley Disposal and Recycling, Inc. has contracted through
2017 with the Salinas Valley Solid Waste Authority to dispose of municipal solid waste at Crazy
Horse Sanitary Landfill and Johnson Canyon Sanitary Landfill. Crazy Horse Sanitary Landfill is
anticipated to reach capacity in 2009 and Johnson Canyon Sanitary Landfill is anticipated to reach
capacity in 2043. 19

Pacific Gas and Electric provide electricity and natural gas to the project area.



16
   City of Morgan Hill, Water System Master Plan, January 2002.
17
   City of Morgan Hill, Sewer System Master Plan, January 2002
18
   City of Morgan Hill, Storm Drainage System Master Plan, January 2002.
19
   Phil Couchee, General Manager, South Valley Disposal and Recycling, Inc. Personal Communication. May 18,
2009.

4.16.2.1        Impacts from the Proposed Project

The project proponent proposes a General Plan amendment to change the land use designation on the
site from Public Facilities to Single Family Medium (3-5 dwelling units per acre). This will allow
the future development of up to 150 single-family units on the site.




City of Morgan Hill                                                                                          Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                            94                                                 August 2009
The potential addition of up to 150 residences on the project site would result in an increase in water
usage, sanitary sewer, waste generation, electricity, and gas usage from the site. Residential
development would be subject to the City's Residential Development Control System (RDCS). The
RDCS process would ensure consistency with the growth rate in the General Plan and, therefore,
would not exceed the City's planned water, wastewater treatment, or solid waste demand.

The proposed project, however, would increase the amount of impervious surfaces on the site,
therefore, increasing the amount of runoff generated by the proposed project.

4.16.2.1        Program Mitigation and Avoidance Measures

Many of the policies in the City's General Plan were adopted for the purpose of avoiding or
mitigating potential environmental effects that could result from planned development within the
City. All future development would be subject to General Plan policies, including the following,
conformance with which will reduce utilities and service system impacts to a less than significant
level:

                                       Morgan Hill General Plan

       Sewer Capacity, Water Supply and Storm Drainage Policy 20a - Expansion of the joint
        Gilroy/Morgan Hill Wastewater Treatment Facility should proceed, since additional sewer
        capacity is a prerequisite for further urban development and urban development is most
        appropriately served by sanitary sewer systems. (SCJAP 6.00)

       Sewer Capacity, Water Supply and Storm Drainage Policy 20c - Ensure that the total
        capacity for the Gilroy/Morgan Hill Wastewater Treatment Facility, its timing for
        completion, and configuration are consistent with SCJAP policies for the overall growth of
        Morgan Hill and Gilroy.

       Sewer Capacity, Water Supply and Storm Drainage Policy 21a - Manage the supply and use
        of water more efficiently through appropriate means, such as watershed protection,
        percolation, conservation and reclamation. (SCJAP 7.00)

       Sewer Capacity, Water Supply and Storm Drainage Policy 21b - Ensure that new
        development does not exceed the water supply. (SCJAP 7.08)

       Sewer Capacity, Water Supply and Storm Drainage Policy 22a - Address issues related to
        flooding throughout the city.

       Sewer Capacity, Water Supply and Storm Drainage Policy 22b - Ensure that those residents
        who benefit from, as well as those who contribute to the need for, local drainage facilities pay
        for them. (SCJAP 13.02)

       Water Quality Policy 6d - Work jointly with Gilroy and Santa Clara County to achieve a
        balance between potential negative impacts and the benefits associated with the location of
        solid waste disposal sites and transfer stations. (SCJAP 8.10)




City of Morgan Hill                                                                         Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                    95                                        August 2009
4.16.3          Conclusion

The proposed General Plan amendment would not significantly increase demand for utility services
and systems. (Less Than Significant Impact)

Discussion: With the implementation of mitigation measures described in this report, the proposed
General Plan amendment, alone or considered in combination with other General Plan amendments,
would not result in significant environmental impacts. Future development on the site is subject to
applicable policies of the General Plan and existing laws and regulations as described in this Initial
Study.

4.17.1           Cumulative Global Climate Change Effects

Global climate change is the alteration of the Earth's weather including its temperature, precipitation,
and wind patterns. Global temperatures are affected by naturally occurring and anthropogenic-
generated atmospheric gases, such as carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide. These gases allow
sunlight into the Earth's atmosphere, but prevent radiative heat from escaping into outer space, which
is known as the "greenhouse" effect. The world's leading climate scientists have reached consensus
that global climate change is underway and is very likely caused by humans. 20



20
  IPCC, 2007: Summary for Policymakers. In: Climate Change 2007: The Physical Science Basis. Contribution of
Working Group I to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change [Solomon, S.,
D. Qin, M. Manning, Z. Chen, M. Marquis, K.B. Averyt, M. Tignor and H.L. Miller (eds.)]. Cambridge University
Press, Cambridge, United Kingdom and New York, NY, USA. Available at: http://www.ipcc.ch/.

City of Morgan Hill                                                                                             Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                           97                                                     August 2009
Agencies at the international, national, state, and local levels are considering strategies to control
emissions of gases that contribute to global warming. There is no comprehensive strategy that is
being implemented on a global scale that addresses climate change; however, in California steps are
being taken to address climate change. A multi-agency "Climate Action Team" was set up to
implement Executive Order S-3-05 (signed by the Governor of California in 2005), under which the
state plans to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to 80 percent below 1990 levels by 2050.

California Assembly Bill 32 (AB 32), signed into law in 2006, requires achievement of a statewide
greenhouse gas emissions limit by 2020 equivalent to 1990 emissions. On December 11, 2008, the
California Air Resources Board (ARB) approved a key requirement of AB 32, the Climate Change
Scoping Plan. 21 The Scoping Plan proposes a comprehensive set of actions designed to reduce
overall carbon emissions in California, improve our environment, reduce our dependence on oil,
diversify our energy sources, save energy, and enhance public health while creating new jobs and
enhancing the growth in California's economy. The ARB is currently working on additional
regulations to implement the Scoping Plan. AB 32 requires the adoption of rules and regulations to
achieve the maximum technologically feasible and cost-effective greenhouse gas emissions
reductions by January 1, 2011.

4.17.1.1        Project Impacts

Currently there is no established guidance, from the state or in published CEQA case law, for the
determination of what constitutes a significant global climate change impact or what measures are
necessary to off-set new greenhouse gas emissions. The Governor's Office of Planning and Research
(OPR) is currently developing amendments to the CEQA Guidelines that will provide regulatory
guidance on the analysis and mitigation for Greenhouse Gas Emissions (GHG) in CEQA documents.
Under Senate Bill 97, these amendments are to be adopted on or before January 1, 2010. In the
interim, OPR has prepared a technical guidance document regarding the steps lead agencies should
take to address climate change in their CEQA documents. 22 The guidance document recommends
that the Lead Agency identify individual or cumulative impacts of a project and mitigation measures
to reduce greenhouse gas emissions associated with transportation, electricity generation and use, and
other sources.

The proposed General Plan amendment would allow the future development of up to 150 single
family residences on the site. Projects such as the proposed future development would generate
greenhouse gases primarily through electricity use and generation of vehicle trips. It is estimated that
future development of 150 single family residences on the site would increase the emission of carbon
dioxide by approximately 2,684 tons (or 2,435 metric tons) per year, according to the
URBEMIS2007 model (refer to Appendix B). Construction of 150 single family residences would
result in the emission of approximately 415 tons (or 376 metric tons) of carbon dioxide.

In an effort to make a good faith effort at disclosing environmental impacts and to conform with the
CEQA Guidelines [16064(b)], it is the City's position that, based on the City's Residential
Development Control System (RDCS) ordinance which limits the level of residential growth in the
City to 48,000 persons by the year 2020, and the nature and size of the proposed future development,
the proposed project would not impede the state's ability to reach the emission reduction
limits/standards set forth by the State of California by Executive Order S-3-05 and AB 32. For these

21
   California Air Resources Board, http://www.arb.ca.gov/cc/scopingplan/document/scopingplandocument.htm,
accessed December 15, 2008
22
   Governor's Office of Planning and Research, Technical Advisory; CEQA AND CLIMATE CHANGE: Addressing
Climate Change Through California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Review, June 19, 2008.

City of Morgan Hill                                                                          Initial Study
Hale-Signature                                     98                                        August 2009
reasons, this project would not make a cumulatively considerable contribution to global climate
change associated with greenhouse gas emissions.

Conclusion: The proposed project would not result in significant unavoidable impacts or substantial
new cumulative impacts associated with greenhouse gas emissions and global climate change.
(Less Than Significant Impacts)

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
This report presents the results of the transportation impact analysis (TIA) conducted for the proposed
modification in land use designation of the Hale Signature Property in the City of Morgan Hill, California. The
proposed general plan amendment (GPA) will convert 30 vacant acres of Public Facilities to Single Family
Residential Medium (3 to 5 dwelling units per acre) use. The project site is bounded by the Union Pacific Railroad
tracks to the east, residential uses to the south (Campoli Drive) and north (Tarragon Avenue), and Hale Avenue to
the west. To present a more conservative analysis, this report analyzes the project's potential transportation
impacts based on the maximum density (5 units per acre) allowed for the Single Family Residential Medium use.
Therefore, the proposed GPA was assumed to include the development of 150 single family homes.

The purpose of the TIA is to identify any potential significant adverse impacts of the proposed GPA on the
surrounding transportation system and to recommend mitigation measures, if needed. Impacts were evaluated
following the guidelines of the City of Morgan Hill and the Valley Transportation Authority (VTA), the congestion
management agency for Santa Clara County.

PROJECT TRIPS
The proposed GPA allows for the development of up to 150 single family homes on the 30-acre project site based
on the proposed modification in land use designate to Single Family Residential Medium (3 to 5 dwelling units per
acre). Trip generation rates for the GPA were estimated based on rates published for Single-Family Detached
Housing (ITE 210) land use in the Institute of Transportation Engineers' Trip Generation 8th Edition. The
proposed GPA is estimated to generate 1,510 daily trips, 115 AM peak-hour trips and 151 PM peak-hour trips.

2030 GENERAL PLAN CONDITIONS INTERSECTION IMPACTS
Based on impact criteria defined by the City of Morgan Hill the proposed GPA is expected to have less-than-
significant impacts at all of the study intersections. Thus, no measures are necessary to mitigate project impacts.
The results of the level of service (LOS) calculations for all scenarios analyzed for this TIA are summarized in
Table ES-1.

FREEWAY SEGMENT IMPACTS
Based on the VTA's Congestion Management Program guidelines for freeway analyses, the project is not
expected to have a significant impact on the freeway study segments located on US 101.

2030 GENERAL PLAN CUMULATIVE CONDITIONS INTERSECTION OPERATIONS
Based on the City of Morgan Hill's LOS standards, all intersections are projected to operate at acceptable service
levels with the exception of the unsignalized intersection of Hale Avenue/Tilton Avenue. This intersection is
projected to operate at unacceptable LOS E during the morning peak hour. However, the peak hour volume
warrant is not met, and the project would not result in a significant impact at this intersection based on the City's
impact criteria. The results of the level of service (LOS) calculations for all scenarios analyzed for this TIA are
summarized in Table ES-1.

July 6, 2009



1. INTRODUCTION
This report presents the results of the transportation impact analysis (TIA) conducted for the proposed
modification in land use designation of the Hale Signature Property in the City of Morgan Hill, California. The
proposed general plan amendment (GPA) will convert 30 vacant acres of Public Facilities to Single Family
Residential Medium (3 to 5 dwelling units per acre) use. The project site is bounded by the Union Pacific Railroad
tracks to the east, residential uses to the south (Campoli Drive) and north (Tarragon Avenue), and Hale Avenue to
the west. The project site location is shown on the map on Figure 1. Since the proposed project is a GPA and
does not include a specific development proposal, no site plan is currently available for the project. To present a
more conservative analysis this report analyzes the project's potential transportation impacts based on the
maximum density (5 units per acre) allowed for the Single Family Residential Medium use. Therefore, the
proposed GPA was assumed to include the development of 150 single family homes.

The purpose of the TIA is to identify potential significant adverse impacts of the proposed GPA on the surrounding
transportation system and to recommend mitigation measures, if needed. Impacts were evaluated following the
guidelines of the City of Morgan Hill and the Valley Transportation Authority (VTA), the congestion management
agency for Santa Clara County.

This analysis evaluated the operations of eight (8) study intersections, which were selected in consultation with
City staff and based on VTA's guidelines for selecting study intersections:

    1. Hale Avenue and Tilton Avenue                             5. Monterey Road and Burnett Avenue

    2. Hale Avenue and Madrone Parkway (future                   6. Monterey Road and Madrone Parkway
       intersection)
                                                                 7. Monterey Road and Cochrane Road
    3. Hale Avenue and Llagas Road
                                                                 8. Monterey Road and Old Monterey Road
    4. Monterey Road and Tilton Avenue
All intersections are under the jurisdiction of the City of Morgan Hill. Per the City's July 2001 General Plan, the
Madrone Parkway extension crossing between Monterey Road and Hale Avenue is assumed in the 2030 roadway
network. This roadway bisects the 30 acre Hale Signature property.

This study also included evaluation the following US 101 freeway segments (northbound and southbound):

       US 101 between Cochrane Road and Coyote Creek Road

       US 101 between Cochrane Road and Dunne Avenue

Peak traffic conditions generally occur during weekday mornings between 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. and between
4:00p.m. and 6:00 p.m. in the evenings. The operations of the study intersections were evaluated during the
weekday morning (AM) and evening (PM) peak hours for the following four (4) scenarios:

        Scenario 1:      Existing Conditions  Existing volumes obtained from counts, representing peak one-hour
                         traffic conditions during the morning and evening commute periods .

        Scenario 2:      2030 General Plan Baseline Conditions  2030 cumulative traffic volumes based on City
                         provided land use that includes approved and pending development projects, plus
                         roadway improvements from the July 2001 General Plan Circulation Element, which
                         includes the Madrone Parkway extension between Monterey Road and Hale Avenue.



                                                                                                         1
Hale Signature Properties 
Draft Report
July 6, 2009


        Scenario 3:      2030 General Plan with Project Conditions  Traffic projections from Scenario 3 plus
                         traffic estimates from the proposed GPA.

        Scenario 4:      2030 General Plan Cumulative with Conditions  Traffic generated by the 2030 General
                         Plan land uses (Scenario 2) plus trips from the proposed project plus traffic from other
                         pending GPAs.

Intersection impacts of the proposed GPA were evaluated by comparing operations with the 2030 General Plan
with Project Conditions (Scenario 3) to Existing Conditions (Scenario 1) and 2030 General Plan Baseline
Conditions (Scenario 2). Intersection operations under 2030 General Plan Cumulative Conditions are presented
for information purposes to the cumulative impacts of all proposed GPAs in the City of Morgan Hill. The City's
travel demand forecasting model was used to estimate traffic volumes for the 2030 scenarios under scenarios 2
and 4. Freeway impacts of the proposed GPA were evaluated following VTA guidelines and were assessed by
adding project trips to freeway volumes established under Existing Conditions (Scenario 1). Project impacts on
bicycle, pedestrian, and transit facilities and services were also addressed.

The remainder of this report is divided into three chapters.

       Chapter 2  Existing Conditions

       Chapter 3  2030 General Plan Conditions

       Chapter 4  2030 General Plan Cumulative Conditions

A technical appendix is also attached, which contains raw intersection turning movement counts and detailed
operations analysis outputs of information that is referenced in this report.
