2. EXISTING CONDITIONS
This chapter describes the existing conditions of the roadway facilities, pedestrian and bicycle facilities, transit
service, traffic volumes, and intersection operations. A discussion of the method used to calculate intersection
levels of service (LOS) and the corresponding results is also presented in this chapter.

EXISTING ROADWAY NETWORK
This section describes the existing roadway network, which is illustrated on Figure 1. Regional access to the site
is provided via US 101 and local access is provided via Monterey Road, Cochrane Road, Madrone Parkway,
Llagas Road, and Tilton Avenue. Each of these roadways is described below:

U.S. Highway 101 (US 101) is a north-south freeway that serves as the primary roadway connection between
Morgan Hill and all other areas of Santa Clara County. US 101 extends north to San Francisco and south to Los
Angeles. The freeway includes six lanes (three mixed-flow lanes in each direction) within most of Morgan Hill.
North of Cochrane Road, US 101 widens to eight lanes including three mixed-flow lanes and one high occupancy
vehicle (HOV) lane in each direction. HOV lanes, also known as diamond or carpool lanes, restrict use to vehicles
with two or more persons (carpool, vanpool, and buses) or motorcycles during the morning (5:00 AM to 9:00 AM)
and evening (3:00 PM to 7:00 PM) commute periods. The Cochrane Road interchange provides primary access
to the project site.

Monterey Road, through Morgan Hill, is generally a four-lane arterial roadway with separate left-turn lanes at
intersections and on-street parking in some areas. Monterey Road extends from San Jose through the downtown
area of Morgan Hill to the City of Gilroy. The speed limit on Monterey Road varies from 45 miles per hour (mph)
north of Cochrane Road to 25 mph between Main Avenue and East Dunne Avenue in downtown. Several sets of
speed lumps slow traffic through the downtown area.

Cochrane Road is an arterial that extends from Monterey Road east to Anderson Lake. Cochrane Road is a two-
to six-lane facility that provides an interchange with US 101 at the north end of the city. The posted speed limit is
45 mph.

Madrone Parkway is a two-lane undivided collector that extends eastward from its intersection with Monterey
Road and connects with Cochrane Road. The roadway is posted at 35 mph. Per the City's July 2001 General
Plan, Madrone Parkway will be extended westward to provide a connection between Monterey Road and Hale
Avenue. This extension is assumed in the 2030 roadway network.

Llagas Road is a collector that extends eastward from the City's western city limits to Old Monterey Road. The
posted speed limit is 25 mph. Between Old Monterey Road and Llagas Creek Drive, the roadway is a two-lane
road that provides left-turn lanes into the intersecting local streets. West of Llagas Creek Drive, Llagas Road is a
two-lane facility.

Tilton Avenue is two-lane collector road that provides a connection between Hale Avenue and Monterey Road.
The posted speed limit is 35 mph.

EXISTING PEDESTRIAN AND BICYCLE FACILITIES
The mild climate, relatively flat terrain, and proximity of many recreational and non-recreational destinations
provide an ideal environment for walking and bicycling in the City of Morgan Hill. This section describes the
existing pedestrian and bicycle infrastructure.




                                                                                                           4
Hale Signature Properties 
Draft Report
July 6, 2009


Pedestrian Facilities

Pedestrian facilities include sidewalks, crosswalks, pedestrian signals, and off-street paths that are meant to
provide safe and convenient routes for pedestrians to access destinations such as institutions, businesses, public
transportation, and recreation facilities.

Crosswalks are not provided on Tilton Avenue/Hale Avenue and Monterey Road/Tilton Avenue. Other study
intersections provide limited crosswalks in each direction to bring continuity with adjacent sidewalks. Sidewalk
facilities are provided in the following roadway segments within the vicinity of the project.

       Eastside of Hale Avenue between Tilton Avenue and northern end of the project parcel;

       Llagas Road between Hale Avenue and Old Monterey Avenue;

       Westside of Old Monterey Avenue between Llagas Road and Monterey Road;

       Eastside of Monterey Road between Cochrane Road and Old Monterey Road;

       Discontinuous segments alone Monterey Road between Tilton Avenue and Cochrane Road.

Bicycle Facilities

Bikeway planning and design in California typically relies on the guidelines and design standards established by
                                                                                             th
Caltrans in the Highway Design Manual (Chapter 1000: Bikeway Planning and Design, 5 Edition, California
Department of Transportation, January 2001). Chapter 1000 follows standards developed by the American
Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO) and the Federal Highway Administration
(FHWA), and identifies specific design standards for various conditions and bikeway-to-roadway relationships.
Under California Law, bicyclists are allowed to use all roadways in California unless posted closed. Therefore,
even for the roadways that have no designated (or planned) bikeways identified, a majority are open for cycling.

Caltrans standards provide for three (3) distinct types of bikeway facilities, as generally described below and
shown on the accompanying figures.

       Class I Bikeway (Bike Path) provides a completely separate right-of-way and is designated for the
        exclusive use of bicycles and pedestrians with vehicle and pedestrian cross-flow minimized. In general,
        bike paths serve corridors not served by streets and highways or where sufficient right-of-way exists to
        allow such facilities to be constructed away from the influence of parallel streets and numerous vehicle
        conflicts.




                                                                                                        5
Hale Signature Properties 
Draft Report
July 6, 2009


       Class II Bikeways (Bike Lanes) are lanes for bicyclists adjacent to the outer vehicle travel lanes. These
        lanes have special lane markings, pavement legends, and signage. Bicycle lanes are generally five (5)
        feet wide. Adjacent vehicle parking and vehicle/pedestrian cross-flow are permitted.




       Class III Bikeway (Bike Route) are designated by signs or pavement markings for shared use with
        pedestrians or motor vehicles, but have no separated bike right-of-way or lane striping. Bike routes serve
        either to: a) provide continuity to other bicycle facilities, or b) designate preferred routes through high
        demand corridors.




Figure 2 shows the existing bicycle facilities in and near the project site. No Class I bike paths exist in the project
vicinity. Class II bike are located along the following roadways in the study area:

       Monterey Road north of Cochrane Road;

       Monterey Road south of Old Monterey Road;

       Cochrane Road between Monterey Road and Sutter Boulevard;

       Hale Avenue; and

       Llagas Road west of Monterey Road.

Class III bike routes are provided on Monterey Road between Cochrane Road and Old Monterey Road.

EXISTING TRANSIT SERVICE
The Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority (VTA) operates fixed route, commuter, and paratransit bus
service and light rail service (LRT) in Santa Clara County. VTA provides two bus routes (one local and one
regional) that serve the project area. The Peninsula Corridor Joint Powers Board operates Caltrain commuter rail

service between San Francisco and San Jose, with weekday commute-hour service to Morgan Hill and Gilroy.
Existing transit service near the project is illustrated on Figure 3 and is discussed in more detail below.

Route 16, a local community bus, provides service between the Morgan Hill Civic Center and Burnett Avenue.
Service operates on weekdays only, every 60 minutes from 6:30 AM to 6:00 PM.

Route 68, a regional bus route, provides service between the City of Gilroy Caltrain/Greyhound Station and the
San Jose Diridon Caltrain Station. Service operates on weekdays every 30 minutes from 4:15 AM to 1:20 AM and
on weekends every 30 minutes from 5:45 AM to 1:20 AM.

Caltrain provides frequent daily train service between San Jose and San Francisco. Service extends south to
Gilroy through Morgan Hill during commute periods, with three northbound trips during the AM peak period and
three southbound trips during the PM peak period stopping at the Morgan Hill Caltrain Station located on
Monterey Road south of Main Street.

EXISTING VOLUMES AND LANE CONFIGURATIONS
The operations of the study intersections were evaluated during the weekday AM and PM peak hours.
Intersection operations were evaluated for the highest one-hour volume counted between each of the 7:00 and
9:00 AM and the 4:00 and 6:00 PM peak periods. Intersection turning movement counts were conducted in May
2008. The traffic counts are included in Appendix A.

Figure 4 presents the existing AM and PM peak-hour turning movement volumes, the existing intersection lane
configurations, and traffic control devices for the eight study intersections.

EXISTING LEVEL OF SERVICE METHODS AND POLICIES
The operations of roadway facilities are described with the term level of service (LOS). LOS is a qualitative
description of traffic flow based on such factors as speed, travel time, delay, and freedom to maneuver. Six levels
are defined from LOS A, with the least congested operating conditions, to LOS F, with the most congested
operating conditions. LOS E represents "at-capacity" operations. Operations are designated as LOS F when
volumes exceed capacity, resulting in stop-and-go conditions.

Signalized Intersections

The LOS method for signalized intersections approved by the City of Morgan Hill and VTA analyzes intersection
operations based on average control vehicular delay, as described in Chapter 16 of the 2000 Highway Capacity
Manual (HCM) published by the Transportation Research Board, with adjusted saturation flow rates to reflect
conditions in Santa Clara County. Control delay includes initial deceleration delay, queue move-up time, stopped
delay, and final acceleration delay. The average control delay for signalized intersections is calculated using
TRAFFIX analysis software and is correlated to a LOS designation as shown in Table 1.

Unsignalized Intersections

Operations of the unsignalized study intersections are evaluated using the method contained in Chapter 17 of the
2000 HCM and calculated using TRAFFIX analysis software. LOS ratings for stop-sign controlled intersections
are based on the average control delay expressed in seconds per vehicle. At two-way or side-street-stop
controlled intersections, control delay is calculated for each movement, not for the intersection as a whole. For
approaches composed of a single lane, delay is computed as the average of all movements in that lane. For all-

way stop-controlled locations, a weighted average delay for the entire intersection is presented. Table 2
summarizes the relationship between delay and LOS for unsignalized intersections.

General Plan Circulation Element LOS Policy

The City of Morgan Hill currently maintains a minimum acceptable operating level of LOS D+ (i.e., less than 39.0
seconds of delay) for local signalized intersections and LOS E at freeway ramp intersections. Per the City of
Morgan Hill General Plan (July 2001), the Madrone Parkway/Monterey Road study intersection is one of three
signalized intersections that are allowed to operate at LOS D (up to 55 seconds of delay), where achieving LOS
D+ would require extraordinary development expenditure and right-of-way acquisition.

The City has generally used a minimum acceptable operating level of LOS D for unsignalized intersections and
peak hour signal warrant analysis to identify significant traffic impacts.


                                                    TABLE 1
                              SIGNALIZED INTERSECTION LEVEL OF SERVICE DEFINITIONS
                                   USING AVERAGE CONTROL VEHICULAR DELAY

                                                                                                     Average Control Delay Per
Level of Service                                    Description                                         Vehicle (Seconds)
       A           Operations with very low delay occurring with favorable progression and/or                    10.0
                                              short cycle lengths.
       B+            Operations with low delay occurring with good progression and/or short                   10.1 to 12.0
       B                                         cycle lengths.                                               12.1 to 18.0
       B-                                                                                                     18.1 to 20.0
       C+             Operations with average delays resulting from fair progression and/or                   20.1 to 23.0
       C                 longer cycle lengths. Individual cycle failures begin to appear.                     23.1 to 32.0
       C-                                                                                                     32.1 to 35.0
       D+               Operations with longer delays due to a combination of unfavorable                     35.1 to 39.0
       D             progression, long cycle lengths, and high V/C ratios. Many vehicles stop                 39.1 to 51.0
       D-                           and individual cycle failures are noticeable.                             51.1 to 55.0
       E+           Operations with high delay values indicating poor progression, long cycle                 55.1 to 60.0
       E               lengths, and high V/C ratios. Individual cycle failures are frequent                   60.1 to 75.0
       E-                                         occurrences.                                                75.1 to 80.0
       F           Operations with delays unacceptable to most drivers occurring due to over-                   > 80.0
                            saturation, poor progression, or very long cycle lengths.
 Source: Traffic Level of Service Analysis Guidelines, VTA Congestion Management Program, June 2003; Highway Capacity Manual,
        Transportation Research Board, 2000.




                                                                                                                         11
Hale Signature Properties

July 6, 2009

                            UNSIGNALIZED INTERSECTION LEVEL OF SERVICE DEFINITIONS


                                                                                                     Average Control Delay Per
Level of Service                                     Description                                        Vehicle (Seconds)
        A                                         Little or no delay.                                             10.0
        B                                        Short traffic delays.                                        10.1 to 15.0
        C                                      Average traffic delays.                                        15.1 to 25.0
        D                                        Long traffic delays.                                         25.1 to 35.0
        E                                      Very long traffic delays.                                      35.1 to 50.0
        F                   Extreme traffic delays with intersection capacity exceeded.                          > 50.0
 Source: Highway Capacity Manual, Transportation Research Board, 2000.


Freeway Segments

Freeway segments are evaluated using VTA's analysis procedure, which is based on the density of the traffic flow
using methods described in the 2000 HCM. Density is expressed in passenger cars per mile per lane. The
Congestion Management Program range of densities for freeway segment level of service is shown in Table 3.
The LOS standard for the freeway segments is LOS E.

                                                     TABLE 3
                                    FREEWAY SEGMENT LEVEL OF SERVICE DEFINITIONS

                       Level of Service                                    Density (passenger cars per mile per lane)
                                A                                                                 11
                                B                                                            11.1 to 18.0
                                C                                                            18.1 to 26.0
                                D                                                            26.1 to 46.0
                                E                                                            46.1 to 58.0
                                F                                                               > 58.0
Sources: Traffic Level of Service Analysis Guidelines, VTA Congestion Management Program, June 2003; Highway Capacity Manual,
         Transportation Research Board, 2000.


EXISTING INTERSECTION LEVELS OF SERVICE
Existing intersection lane configurations, signal timings, and peak-hour turning movement volumes as illustrated
on Figure 4 were used as inputs for the LOS calculations. The results of the LOS analysis for Existing Conditions
are presented in Table 4. Appendix B contains the corresponding calculation sheets. Measured against the City
of Morgan Hill LOS standard, all study intersections currently operate at acceptable LOS D+ or better during both
peak periods.

FIELD OBSERVATIONS
Field observations of the study intersections were conducted in April 2008 to verify their operations. In general,
observations indicated that all of the study intersections are operating at or near the calculated levels of service.
Queuing was observed at Monterey Road/Burnett Avenue, Cochrane Avenue/Monterey Road, and Old Monterey
Road/Monterey Road. However, most of the vehicle queues typically cleared these intersections within one cycle.
The unsignalized intersection of Hale Avenue/Tilton Avenue was observed to operate acceptably with no
significant queuing.

Field observations at the intersection of Tilton Avenue/Monterey Road verified a preemption phase due to the
passing of trains on the nearby railroad tracks. While the presence of a train temporarily causes queuing that
substantially exceeds typical operations, regular operations and cycle lengths were observed to resume within
two signal cycles or less than five (5) minutes after a train departed the area.




                                                                                                                            13
Hale Signature Properties 
Draft Report
July 6, 2009

freeway segment of southbound US 101 between Coyote Creek Road and Cochrane Road during the PM peak
hour exceeds the VTA's LOS E standard.

3. 2030 GENERAL PLAN CONDITIONS
This chapter describes the expected traffic operations under 2030 General Plan Conditions with and without the
proposed GPA. The City of Morgan Hill travel demand forecasting model was used to estimate 2030 traffic
volumes. 2030 land use and network assumptions are briefly discussed below and followed by a more detailed
discussion of intersection operations.

LAND USE AND TRANSPORTATION NETWORK ASSUMPTIONS
The City's travel demand forecasting model was used to develop 2030 General Plan traffic volume estimates.
2030 land use estimates were based on input from City staff and regionally approved data from the Association of
Bay Area Governments (ABAG). Under 2030 General Plan Baseline Conditions the model includes agricultural
land uses for the project site. To present a more conservative approach, project trips associated with the GPA
were added to the 2030 General Plan Baseline volumes and no trip credits were taken for the agricultural uses
modeled for the site. Included in the model is the planned roadway network based on the 2001 General Plan
Circulation Element. Planned roadway network improvements relevant to the project include:

     1. Construction of the Madrone Parkway as a 4 lane roadway extension between Monterey Road and Hale
        Avenue bisecting the project property and including an underpass at Monterey Road;
     2. Construction of the Llagas Creek Drive as a 2 lane collector between Hale Avenue and Monterey Road;
     3. Widening of Hale Avenue from 2 to 4 lanes from Tilton Avenue to Main Street;
     4. Widening of Monterey Road from 4 to six lanes north of Cochrane Road;
     5. Widening of Monterey Road from 2 to 4 lanes south of Cochrane Road; and
     6. Widening of Cochrane Road from 4 to six lanes east of Monterey Road.

2030 GENERAL PLAN BASELINE INTERSECTION TRAFFIC VOLUME ESTIMATES
Using the base year and future year model forecasts, we developed weekday peak-hour forecasts for
intersection turning movements at the eight (8) key intersections within the study area for 2030 General Plan
Baseline Conditions.

For this study, we applied the guidelines published in National Cooperative Highway Research Program (NCHRP)
Report 255 1 to refine the raw model forecasts. This method is based on the difference between counts and model
volumes and helps to provide more reasonable forecasts.

Figure 5 illustrates the AM and PM peak hour intersection turning movement forecasts volumes, intersection lane
configurations, and traffic control devices for the study intersections under 2030 General Plan Baseline
Conditions.




1
 National Cooperative Highway Research Program (NCHRP). Report 255: Highway Traffic Data for Urbanized
Area Project Planning and Design. Washington, D.C.: National Academy Press, 1982.



                                                                                                     15
Hale Signature Properties 
Draft Report
July 6, 2009


2030 GENERAL PLAN BASELINE WITH PRJOECT TRAFFIC VOLUME ESTIMATES
The amount of traffic associated with the project was estimated using a three-step process: (1) trip generation, (2)
trip distribution, and (3) trip assignment. In the first step, the amount of traffic entering and exiting the project area
was estimated on a daily and peak-hour basis. In the second step, the direction vehicles use to approach and
depart the site was estimated. The trips were assigned to specific street segments and intersection turning
movements in the third step and added to the 2030 General Plan Baseline traffic volumes to develop 2030
General Plan Baseline with Project traffic volumes. The results of the process for this analysis are described in
the following sections.

Trip Generation

The proposed GPA allows for the development of up to 150 single family homes on the 30 acres project site. Trip
generation was calculated using rates from the Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) Trip Generation (8th
Edition). The peak-hour trip generation trip estimates for each phase are presented in Table 6. A 150 single
family home development is estimated to generate 1,510 daily trips, 115 AM peak-hour trips (29 inbound and 86
outbound), and 151 PM peak-hour trips (95 inbound and 56 outbound).


                                                         TABLE 6
                                       PROJECT TRIP GENERATION RATES AND ESTIMATES

                                         Daily                     AM Peak-Hour                        PM Peak-Hour
                             Size
          Use               (d.u.)2   Rate1   Trips     Rate1        In         Out    Total   Rate1    In     Out         Total
 Single Family
                             150      10.07   1,510      0.77        29         86     115     1.01     95      56         151
 Dwelling Units3
 Notes:
 1
     Rate per dwelling unit
 2
     d.u. = dwelling unit
 3
     Daily, AM, and PM peak hour trip generation rates based on fitted curve.
 Source: Trip Generation, 8th Edition, Institute of Transportation Engineers (2008).


Trip Distribution

Project trip distribution was primarily based on a select zone analysis using the City's travel demand forecasting
model. Location of supporting land uses in the vicinity of the project area, information from previous traffic studies
in the area, and input from City staff was used to refine the trip distribution. Figure 6 shows the proposed trip
distribution for the project. Approximately 40 percent of trips are expected to travel north of the City of Morgan Hill
and 25 percent to destinations south of the City. The remaining trips are spread to destinations within the City of
Morgan Hill.

Trip Assignment

Trips generated by the proposed project were assigned to the roadway system based on the directions of
approach and departure described above. Peak hour project trips are shown on Figure 6. Project-generated trips
were added to the 2030 General Plan Baseline volumes to estimate volumes under 2030 General Plan Baseline
with Project Conditions, which are shown on Figure 7.

2030 GENERAL PLAN INTERSECTION LEVEL OF SERVICE
Existing intersection configurations were modified to accommodate the proposed Madrone Parkway extension
crossing between Monterey Road and Hale Avenue and widened roadways (e.g. Monterey Road widened from 2
to 4 lanes south of Cochrane Road and Hale Avenue widened from 2 to 4 lanes between Tilton Avenue and Main
Street). The lane geometries and signal controls for 2030 General Plan Baseline with Project Conditions are
illustrated on Figure 7.

2030 General Plan roadway intersection lane configurations, signal timings, and peak-hour turning movement
volumes were used as inputs for the LOS calculations. The results of the LOS analysis for 2030 General Plan with
Project Conditions are presented in Table 7. Appendix B contains the corresponding calculation sheets.
Measured against the City's current LOS D+ standard for signalized intersections (LOS D is acceptable for the
Madrone Parkway/Monterey Road intersection) all of the study intersection would operate at acceptable levels.

2030 GENERAL PLAN SIGNAL WARRANT ANALYSIS
The peak-hour signal warrant from the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) was evaluated for
the unsignalized intersection that operates unacceptably under 2030 General Plan Conditions to determine if a
traffic signal is warranted. The unsignalized Hilton Avenue/Tilton Avenue intersection is projected to operate at
acceptable levels in 2030, and no signal warrant analysis was performed.

2030 GENERAL PLAN FREEWAY ANALYSIS
According to CMP guidelines, freeway segments to which a proposed development is projected to add trips equal
to or greater than one percent of the freeway segment's capacity must be evaluated. The freeway segments
immediately north and south of Cochrane Road were reviewed to determine if a significant amount of project
traffic would be added to these freeway segments. Capacities of 2,300 vehicles per hour per lane (vphpl) for
freeway segments with three or more lanes and capacities of 2,200 vphpl for freeway segments with two lanes
were used in the freeway analysis. To be conservative, no project trips were assigned to HOV lanes.

Table 8 outlines the estimated number of net new trips added to the freeway segments under 2030 General Plan
with Project Conditions. The proposed project would not add new trips greater than one percent of the freeway
segment capacity to any of the study freeway segments. Therefore, no additional freeway segment analysis is
required for the proposed project.

SIGNIFICANT IMPACT CRITERIA
The results of the level of service calculations for Existing Conditions were compared to the results for 2030
General Plan Baseline with Project Conditions to identify significant impacts. The following standards of
significance apply to the transportation impacts discussed in this study. These standards are consistent with the
Guidelines for Preparation of Transportation Impact Reports (City of Morgan Hill, May 2008).

Signalized Intersection Impact Criteria

The City's LOS standard for City intersections is LOS D+ (i.e. less than 39.0 seconds of delay). Per the General
Plan (July 2001), the Madrone Parkway/Monterey Road study intersection is one of three signalized intersections
that are allowed to operate at LOS D (up to 55 seconds of delay), where achieving LOS D+ would require
extraordinary development expenditure and right-of-way acquisition.

The City of Morgan Hill has adopted the signalized intersection impact criteria as defined by the VTA, the
Congestion Management Agency for Santa Clara County. Therefore, traffic impacts at City of Morgan Hill
intersections would occur when the addition of traffic associated with implementation of the Project causes:

      1. Intersection operations to deteriorate from an acceptable level (LOS D+ or better for most intersections
         and LOS D or better for the Madrone Parkway/Monterey Road intersection) under the Existing
         Conditions to an unacceptable level ( LOS D or worse for most intersections and LOS D- or worse for
         the Madrone Parkway/Monterey Road intersection); or,
      2. Exacerbation of unacceptable operations under Existing Conditions by increasing the average
         critical delay by more than 4 seconds and increasing the critical volume-to-capacity (V/C) ratio by




                                                                                                                 22
Hale Signature Properties 
Draft Report
July 6, 2009


          0.01 or more at an intersection operating at LOS E or LOS F under 2030 General Plan Baseline with
          Project Conditions.
None of the intersections analyzed for this report are designated Congestion Management Program (CMP)
intersections.

Unsignalized Intersection Impact Criteria

Levels of service analysis at unsignalized intersections are generally used to determine the need for modification
in type of intersection control (i.e. all-way stop or signalization). As part of this evaluation traffic volumes, delay,
and traffic signal warrants are evaluated to determine if the existing intersection control is appropriate.

The City has generally used a minimum acceptable operating level of LOS D for unsignalized intersections.
Significant impacts are defined to occur when the addition of Project traffic the worst movement/approach to
degrade to LOS E or LOS F and the intersection satisfies the peak hour signal warrants from the MUTCD.

Freeway Impact Criteria

According to VTA's Transportation Impact Analysis Guidelines (VTA, 1998) a freeway segment analysis should
be included if the project meets one of the following requirements:

    1.   The proposed development project is expected to add traffic equal to at least one percent of a freeway
         segment's capacity.
    2.   The proposed development project is adjacent to one of the freeway segment's access or egress points
    3.   Based on engineering judgment, Lead Agency staff determines that the freeway segment should be
         included in the analysis.
According to CMP guidelines, freeway segments with project traffic equal to or greater than one percent of the
freeway segment's capacity must be evaluated. For mixed-flow lanes, freeway segment capacities are defined as
2,200 vehicles per hour per lane (vphpl) for four-lane freeway segments and 2,300 vphpl for six-lane freeway
segments. HOV lane capacities are defined between 1,800 to 1,900 vphpl.

If a project meets the criteria outlined above, then the implementation of the proposed project could result in a
significant impact if the addition of project traffic on a freeway segment exceeded one of the following thresholds:

    1. The addition of project traffic causes the operating level of a freeway segment to deteriorate from LOS E
       or better under Existing Conditions to LOS F; or
    2. The number of new trips added by a proposed project to a segment already operating at LOS F under
       Existing Conditions is more than one percent of the freeway segment capacity.

INTERSECTION IMPACTS AND MITIGATION
The impacts of the proposed project were evaluated by comparing intersection operations with the 2030 General
Plan Baseline with Project to the 2030 General Plan Baseline Conditions using the 2001 General Plan Circulation
Element LOS policies and the significance criteria described above. Based on the analysis presented above the
proposed GPA would have a less-than-significant impact on the study intersections.




                                                                                                            23
Hale Signature Properties 
Draft Report
July 6, 2009


FREEWAY IMPACTS AND MITIGATION
The freeway impacts of the proposed GPA were evaluated based on VTA's guidelines. As shown in Table 8, the
project is not projected to add new trips greater than one percent of the freeway segment capacity to any of the
study freeway segments. Therefore, no additional freeway segment analysis is required for the proposed project
and the GPA would have a less-than-significant impact on the study freeway segments.

PEDESTRIAN, BICYCLE, AND TRANSIT IMPACTS AND MITIGATION
The City's Guidelines for Preparation of Transportation Impact Reports does not specify impact criteria for
pedestrian, bicycle, and transit impacts. However, these impacts are generally evaluated based on whether a
proposed project would: 1) conflict with existing or planned pedestrian, bicycle, or transit facilities, or 2) create
walking, bicycling, or transit use demand without providing adequate and appropriate facilities for non-motorized
mobility.

The proposed GPA is not expected to increase the biking, or transit demand to a level where it could not be
accommodated by existing or planned facilities. To accommodate pedestrian travel, development of the project
site should include the construction of sidewalks on Hale Avenue along the project frontage. On the east side of
the project site, the existing rail road tracks provide a barrier to Monterey Road. The construction of the Madrone
Parkway extension includes an underpass at Monterey Road and the railroad tracks. This project should provide
adequate pedestrian and bicycle access to facilitate connectivity between the proposed and existing residential
developments west of Monterey Road and the land uses to the east. With the provision of sidewalks on Hale
Avenue along the project frontage, the proposed GPA would have a less-than-significant impact on pedestrian,
bicycle, and transit facilities and services.




                                                                                                          24
Hale Signature Properties 
Draft Report
July 6, 2009



4. 2030 GENERAL PLAN CUMULATIVE CONDITIONS
This chapter describes the expected traffic operations under 2030 Conditions with all of the proposed GPAs in
place. This scenario includes model-recommended roadway traffic volumes plus vehicle trips generated by
pending GPA land uses (including the proposed GPA), as well as changes in travel patterns caused by City-
proposed GPA roadway network changes. The City`s travel demand forecasting model was used to estimate
2030 General Plan Cumulative Condition traffic volumes. The proposed GPA land use and network assumptions
are briefly discussed and followed by a more detailed discussion of the resulting intersection operations.

LAND USE AND TRANSPORTATION NETWORK GENERAL PLAN AMENDMENTS
The City's travel demand forecasting model was used to develop 2030 General Plan Cumulative traffic volume
estimates. The 2030 General Plan Cumulative model includes all information from 2030 General Plan Baseline
Conditions, plus changes in the land uses and roadway network based on information from the eight pending
GPAs. In addition to the Hale Signature property GPA analyzed for the report, the following GPAs are included in
the 2030 General Plan Cumulative Conditions' model:

       West Hills Community Church USA: Add parcels totaling 8.7 acres into the Urban Service Area and
        replace approximately 11,600 s.f. of church and school space with approximately 20,000 s.f. of the same
        land use.

       Peet  Trumpp USA: Add 6 acres of single family residences on the west side of Peet Road and north of
        Half Road into the Urban Service Area.

       Monterey  Morgan Hill Bible Church GPA and USA: Add parcels totaling 8.7 acres into the Urban
        Service Area and replace approximately 11,600 s.f. of church and school space with approximately
        20,000 s.f. of the same land use.

       Watsonville  Royal Oaks GPA and USA: Change one parcel from Single Family Medium (3-5 du/ac) to
        Light Commercial/Residential on 8.19 acres at the southwest corner of Watsonville Road and Monterey
        Road, and change a second parcel from Single Family Medium to Multi-Family Medium (14-21 du/ac) on
        7.5 acres on the Watsonville Road, west of Monterey Road.

       Walnut Grove Extension Realignment/Simonsen  DeRose Applications (GPA): Amend General Plan
        Land Use Designation from Multi-Family Low and Commercial to 100 percent Commercial. The
        anticipated square footage for the development will be approximately 113,500 s.f.

       Berg & Berg GPA: The proposed GPA will amend approximately 56 acres of Industrial to a combination of
        Commercial and Multi-Family Low, Multi-Family Medium, and the new Single Family High (5-11 du/acre)
        land use designation the City is creating in conjunction with its 2009 Housing Element Update. The
        proposed land uses include approximately 446 small-lot single family residential units (which may be
        "senior housing" but which are analyzed as standard housing units), about 60 apartment units, and about
        25,000 square feet of retail commercial uses. This project is generally bounded by the Union Pacific
        Railroad tracks to the west, Jarvis Drive to the north, Sutter Boulevard to the south, Butterfield Boulevard
        to the east.

       Downtown Specific Plan: This amendment also includes Downtown Redevelopment, Dunne
        Avenue/Depot Street: This application proposes to redevelop the Downtown area with approximately
        1,204 residential units and approximately 186,000 s.f. of retail space relative to existing uses. The




                                                                                                         25
Hale Signature Properties 
Draft Report
July 6, 2009


           Downtown area is generally bounded by Depot Street on the east, Dunne Avenue on the south, Del
           Monte Street on the west and Main Avenue on the north. The list of eight pending GPA includes the
           proposed GPA for the Hale-Signature Properties project.

In addition to the network changes bases on the pending GPAs, the 2030 General Plan Cumulative roadway
network includes the "Model-Recommended Roadway Capacity General Plan Amendments" and City-initiated
roadway network amendments. Compared to the network assumption under 2030 General Plan Baseline
Conditions, the following roadway network differences are relevant to the proposed GPA and study locations:

       1. Hale Avenue will be maintained as a 2 lane road and will not be widened to 4 lanes
       2. Madrone Parkway extension will be constructed as a 2 lane road instead of 4 lanes

All other network assumptions from the 2030 General Plan Baseline Conditions that are directly applicable to the
study intersection remain in effect.

GENERAL PLAN CUMULATIVE TRAFFIC VOLUMES AND LANE CONFIGURATIONS
The same forecast method discussed in Chapter 3 was used for the intersection study locations under 2030
General Plan Cumulative Conditions. Figure 8 shows the AM and PM peak hour intersection turning movement
forecasts volumes, intersection lane configurations, and traffic control devices for eight study intersections under
2030 General Plan Cumulative Conditions.

GENERAL PLAN CUMULATIVE INTERSECTION LEVELS OF SERVICE
2030 General Plan Cumulative intersection lane configurations, signal timings, and peak-hour turning movement
volumes were used as inputs for the LOS calculations. The results of the LOS analysis for 2030 General Plan
Cumulative Conditions are presented in Table 10. Appendix B contains the corresponding calculation sheets.
Measured against the 2001 General Plan Circulation Element LOS standards, the following study intersection will
operate unacceptably under this scenario:

    Int. # 1.   Hale Avenue/Tilton Avenue  This all-way stop controlled intersection will operate at LOS E with an
                average delay of 42.2 seconds during the AM peak period. The northbound approach would operate
                at LOS F and the southbound and westbound approaches would operate at LOS B or better.

The Monterey Road/Madrone Parkway would operate at LOS D with 41.7 second of average intersection delay
during the morning peak period. This intersection is one three signalized intersections that the City's LOS
standards allows to operate at LOS D (up to 55 seconds of delay); therefore this intersection would operate
acceptably. The remaining six study intersections are projected to operate at acceptable LOS D+ or better.

GENERAL PLAN CUMULATIVE SIGNAL WARRANT ANALYSIS
The peak-hour signal warrant from the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) was evaluated for
the unsignalized intersection that is projected to operate unacceptably under 2030 General Plan Cumulative
Conditions to determine if a traffic signal is warranted. 2 Under this scenario, the Hale Avenue/Tilton Avenue

    to install new traffic signals. It estimates future development-generated traffic compared against a sub-set of the standard
    traffic signal warrants recommended in the Federal Highway Administration Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices and



                                                                                                                     26

intersection would operate at unacceptable LOS E with 42.2 seconds of delay during the morning peak hour and
at acceptable LOS C during the evening peak hour. The result of the peak-hour warrant analysis indicates that the
intersection does not satisfy the peak hour warrant analysis (see Appendix C).

 associated California MUTCD guidelines. This analysis should not serve as the only basis for deciding whether and when to
 install a signal. To reach such a decision, the full set of warrants should be investigated based on field-measured, rather
 than forecast, traffic data and a thorough study of traffic and roadway conditions by an experienced engineer. Furthermore,
 the decision to install a signal should not be based solely upon the warrants, since the installation of signals can lead to
 certain types of collisions. The City of Morgan Hill should undertake regular monitoring of actual traffic conditions and
 accident data, and timely re-evaluation of the full set of warrants in order to prioritize and program intersections for
 signalization.

GENERAL PLAN CUMULATIVE INTERSECTION OPERATIONS SUMMARY
Based on the City of Morgan Hill's LOS standards, none of the study intersections are projected to be significantly
impacted by the proposed GPA. Thus, no intersection mitigation measures are required.

The unsignalized intersection Hale Avenue/Tilton Avenue intersection is expected to operate at unacceptable
levels during the AM peak hour. However, this intersection would not meet the Peak Hour Warrant for traffic
signal installation during either peak period. Based on the City's impact criteria this intersection would not be
considered to have a significant impact and signalization would not be required. However, the City of Morgan Hill
should continue to monitor this location and conduct an engineering study to evaluate the need for signals and/or
turn movement restrictions as appropriate to maintain acceptable intersection operations.

SIGNAL WARRANT ANALSYIS
SJ08-1049 Hale Signature Property TIA                                           6/26/2009              Hale-Tilton 2030 GP Cumulative_AM
                                                                                                                    WARRANT 3B (URBAN)

    Warrant 3B: Peak Hour Volume
    The peak hour volume warrant is satisfied when the plotted point representing the vehicles per hour
    on the major street (total of both approaches) and the corresponding vehicles per hour of the higher
    volume minor street approach (one direction only) for one hour (any four consecutive 15-minute
    periods) of an average day falls above the curve in Figure 4-5 for the existing combination of
    approach lanes.

    Analysis

                                                        No of lanes
                                       Major Street                      1
                                       Minor Street                      1

                                                             Peak Hour
                                                                Vehicles Per Hour
                                              Time        Major Street        Minor street
                                                         (Sum of both        (High volume
                                                         approaches)           approach)
                                             7:00 AM        1,020                 80



                                                       FIGURE 4C-3. PEAK HOUR VOLUME WARRANT

                                       700
        MINOR STREET - HIGHER VOLUME




                                       600
                                                                                  2 OR MORE LANES & 2 OR MORE LANES
                                       500
               APPROACH (VPH)




                                                                                        2 OR MORE LANES & 1 LANE
                                       400

                                       300
                                                                                                    1 LANE & 1 LANE

                                       200
                                                                                                                              *150
                                       100                                                                                    *100

                                        0
                                         400           600         800           1000        1200      1400      1600      1800
                                                              MAJOR STREET - TOTAL OF BOTH APPROACHES (VPH)

     *Note: 150 vph applies as the lower threshold volume for a minor street approach
     with two or more lanes and 100 vph applies as the lower threshold volume for
     minor street approach with one or lane.
